reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in this early alpha state, the game sets itself apart in more ways than I can go into here.  There is a sense of freedom in this game that is thoroughly refreshing.  It is clear that Larian Studios has put a great deal of thought, time and effort into this already.  It's easy to get drawn in to what you are doing because the environment reacts accordingly.  You are free to develop your character outside of class boundaries.  You are encouraged to develop the characters individually.  The player isn't forced to play the characters as friends.  They can argue and have disputes, intimidate, charm and convince one another.  This I found to be particularly appealing, and it went a long way towards drawing me in.  For the most part, the dialog choices aren't your standard Good, Neutral and Bad either, which is also nice.  There is no moral compass other than the one you bring.  The fact that Larian has made a genuine effort to address these possibilities speaks volumes to the direction and depth they're bringing to the title.
Larian has taken that same approach with the players interaction with the environment.  The player isn't in a static environment and has a level of interaction with the environment that is unparalled in games of this type.  This sense of freedom, of what can/should/would I do? is throughout all aspects of the game, from the pacing to the crafting system and all of the other things I have yet to try.  It does a great job of keeping you curious, entertained and occupied because there is very little in this game that is linear or forced upon the player.  I find it easy to get drawn into the world they are building because I can do things in the time and manner of my choosing.  With what theyve got going on with the character development, the environment, the crafting, the magic system, the audio, and everything else Larian has demonstrated a fantastic creative spirit and attention to detail.

reviewText:
I've never had a more difficult time rating a game than Divinity Original Sin because 1) It's one of a kind. 2) Expectations were quite high for an epic RPG 3) There are so few decent turn-based and even real-time with pause RPGs so it *had* to be good, just had to...or else it was back to replays of old favorites (again).

I will give it two ratings, one for my experience and one tempered with others' feedback in consideration (see below) as my personal experience score is both lower and possibly atypical.

Overall, I give it 4 out of 5 stars.

The breakdown:

Interactive environment (5)

Story/dialog/pace - drags on, not inspiring (3)

Companions  (2) lifeless (correction - 1 point for ability, 1 for existence)

Graphics (4.5)

Combat  (3.5) --repetitive, but neat spells/skills.

Music (3.8) Edit  -- 4+ as standalone and main theme, in particular, but not in-game. Mostly very light and less inspiring in context of the atmosphere, unlike other Divinity games.

Overall enemy variety & game world (5)

Leveling (3.5) - slow and unrewarding though refreshingly different with Action Points.

Dependability/bugs (3.5) --needs a few more patches but is mostly smooth.

Replayabilty (4) (if you like it yes, if not, no)

Gameplay Hours - (5) Fantastic! 60-150 hours.

Tactics -- lots of cheese/repetition (3.5)

Mods/Editor - (potentially 5 but to be determined).

Voice acting (3) - limited.

Loot (5) For loot maniacs. May be overabundant for some players.

Quests  (4) --better than average, not so fetchy.

Puzzles - Yes - love or hate them

Atmosphere  (3) e.g. lack of dynamic weather, immersive sound and dungeons are not scary.

Dynamic Events - largely absent

Consequences - few or not impacting other than in combat.

Map / Inventory/Journal  (2.5 to 3)

Crafting - (3.5)

A problem with the game is that the sum is not greater than its parts. It would make a much better 30-40 hour game than an  epic-length one, in its current state given it stalls out for story-driven, if not combat, players.

But, if you come to the game with no expectations of Baldur's Gate et al. and in a light-hearted mood (for tis not a dark/mature game) your money should be well-spent. You may even love the game, some really do.

If you're looking for the next epic classic RPG,though, you're on the road to disappointment. So come equipped with an open-mind for best results.

***If you like turn-based RPGs Divinity Original Sin is most worth taking a look at *** and it may well one day be considered a cult classic as the niche following is strong.

----------------------

My personal experience rating, however, is 3.5 -3.8.

I'm an older gamer and don't necessarily represent the majority of Larian fans, though love most of their games. Original Sin started as a holiday dinner and soon became two-day old, leftover turkey sandwiches after 40ish hours -- stale and bland, though a bit tasty with salt when available. I actually quit the game 3/4 the way through, from boredom,though plan to return to it someday (tm).

My standards are rather distinct for an RPG and in disclosure I lean strongly towards Neverwinter Nights series or Baldur's Gate-type games (aside from strategy, open-world and select aRPGs) as well as those with darker undertones.

Additionally, I even felt Shadowrun,  XCom and Disciples combat was much more enjoyable. I think with mods this game could turn around. Right now it is a diamond in the rough, or so it appears. Multiplayer may offer a ton of fun and that I am unable to comment on.

Lastly, of note, my Steam hours are artificially inflated -- both with Alpha and leaving the game running. The real-hours are closer to 150, but nonetheless I well got my money's worth at that rate. The game is better than average but needs serious work to shine.

Most importantly, it needs a soul.

Still, future games in this genre will have a new threshold to meet in modernized cRPGs.

reviewText:
While people across the web compare D:OS to games like Baldur's Gate and older TES series, there is a series that does a much better comparison job imo - Ultima!
It is common for all old RPGs not to lead a player through with objective markers and scalable content, but Ultima games were unique because of the interactivity.
Original Sin does a great job expanding this concept; all the ways player can interact with the world around: move things, break things, create things - affects gaming experience, from immersion to actual combat tactics. The overall game design perfectly complements those interactive mechanics, creating a dense and rich gameplay.

An absolute must see for every RPG fan, new or old alike, even if only to understand how far the genre deviated for the last decades and what RPGs used to be about.

reviewText:
Though I'm only 18 hours in as of this point, I must say it is the best cRpg I've played... It might not mean much seeing as I've only played baldur's gate 2 and drakensang before this, but this game should set an example to all future RPG games. The interactivity is amazing, if it's not the ground/a building you can interact with it, and in many ways. Even things that would be trivial in other games like crates and barrels, load up your inventory with them, go into combat, and make a maze while you're in combat, or sneaking around and dropping them off while you scurry back a safe distance to initiate.

Another thing that stands out is that EVERY stat/talent/ability matters, and you should have each member be varied in what they're expertised in so that you have someone for every situation. Perception lets you spot secrets/traps/switches, and is even needed for discovering things in the main story to continue so it's not just a trivial stat that you can reload every time you step on a trap, Having a character with leadership grants a boost to your whole parties initiative, damage, precision and so forth. Having a loremaster lets you identify items, enemies, and objects... and so on.

The crafting system is pretty nice too, generally if you think two items should combine they generally do. For example, a branch + nine inch nails would make a spiked club, though if things don't combine you may need a higher crafting level :P.

There's absolutely NO hand holding, past a few tutorial popups which just tell you the basics, When you're initiating a quest, you're expected to read through and actually find this location without any help markers, no ignoring the story you must read some of the finer details.

The things I've listed above are only what's on the surface, It's a very deep and detailed game, and compared to modern rpgs, a godsend. I wholly recommend this to anyone who is interested in classic rpgs, and even modern rpg fans (though the difficulty may be a bit much for a casual ;), there is an easy setting... I haven't tried it though, I hear it's much easier than default though.)

reviewText:
This will be a cult-classic, turn-based, role-playing game in the years to come. .

10/10

The Great:
*Good* graphics
Fresh role-playing system: Spells, talents and attribute are fresh and work well together
Flexibility in character creation: Classless development

bolt through the blood on the ground.

Complex and extensive Crafting
Game Editor made available by the developer
Active support by the developer post-release including patches, free DLC, and intimated (but un-specified) additions to the engine
Much better than a real-time with pause engine

The Standard:
Role-playing

What you might not like:
Not an Action RPG"
Requires some thought for everything - either expect to spend some time or look up a wiki / guide (well worth the effort put in)

Not many mods created"

reviewText:
While the game still has some bugs and rough edges (such as stat-reset in multiplayer upon joining and the animation skeleton showing when using some skills, etc), the game itself more than makes up for it.

There is plenty to do and much to explore - it manages to appeal to both modern game lovers and oldschool gamers, combining modern and old into a working package of grand adventure. The gameplay is clever and interesting, allowing for different ways of solving fights and problems. Characters and interaction are especially good and differ from the norm for these kinds of games. The co-op makes for a fun way of playing, while single player allows for being nitpicky to the most minor of details.

Combined with a good soundtrack, pleasing art style and some solid story and gameplay, this game is a good addition to anyone's library.

Divinity Original Sin is an excellent title - especially from an indie studio. This is easily the best rpg of this style I have played in over a decade.

The community's reviews are spot on for the most part (about the awesomeness of this game), but I just want to point out a few things that I felt the game could improve on:

- The game has a steep learning curve (I actually enjoyed this and it was my favorite part about the game). But here was the issue. Once I figured out the learning curve and learned the mechanics, the game suddenly felt too easy and exploitable. Some of the mechanics are far too overpowered once you understand how they interact. In this sense, it was extremely gratifying to get to this point, but once this point of understanding was achieved, I became incredibly bored. Even on the hardest difficulty you can simply out-mechanic" the game by using cheese tactics. Some skills need to be rebalanced.

- The inventory system is awkwardly tedious. I won't go in depth but the way the loot is split between your characters and split gold and all that nonsense... it just adds more micromanagement. I understand this is more realistic

reviewText:
One of the best RPGs i've played in a long time. When i started playing it i expected it to be Baldur's Gate's spiritual successor, and while that's not really the case it is still a great game in it's own right. And it took me 85 hours to complete one playthrough, that's like... 20 times more than the average game nowdays.

The combat system is fenomenal, possibly the best part of the game. Turn-based might sound boring to a lot of people, but if you give it a chance it's surprising how addicting it gets once the battle starts. Think of it like X-COM, but without the clunky movement and horrible RNG. And way more abilities.

The main story isn't the game's strongest aspect, and while i wouldn't call it generic i'd say it's quite forgettable. However the world is filled with the usual Larian tongue-in-cheek humor, similar to games like Sacred 2, and many interesting encounters such as talking wells and a romantic sidequest between two cats.

The music is great to listen to and doesn't get repetitive. There's a lack of voiced dialogue but this is already taken care of in the Enhanced Edition.

My only complaints are the lack of banter between party members and the awful rock-paper-scissors minigame when there are decisions to be made, which works well in co-op but is complete garbage when playing alone.

I recommend it to anyone interested in RPGs.

reviewText:
Including offline time at this point i've put in about 10 hours towards the game. At first I was a little hesitant, as it wasn't what I had expected and it seemed super slow almost to the point of being turned off. But I stuck it out and i'm really glad that I did...

Negative first. Foremost I must say that this is truly the only negative thing that I have to say at all. I want more information on character building BEFORE I make my character. I was not originally aware that you must save skill points to further upgrade those skills later - this was a major mistake and i was forced to reset my game so as not to of wasted any skill points nonchalantly. Secondly, I think more emphasis should be put on how important it is to make your party varied in the elemental arts as well as the NEED for a ranged character. So far the best group i've come up with is a mage and a thief/mage (splitting elemental types between them), an archer and a high defense, high constituition knight of sorts. Variety in your skills is MANDO! And make your characters masters of ONE or TWO set of skills. Do not make jack of all trades - it will weaken your part as a whole.

COMBAT:
The turn based combat delivered on a high level and surpassed the high standards that I had for it. I truly enjoy ALL aspects of combat from ranged skills and melee / rogue type abilities to the more jaw dropping elemental magics that intertwine with the local environment. For example, I electrocuted an Orc Shaman while he was standing in a puddle. It just so happens that his two body guards were standing in the same puddle. BAM! All three instantly damaged and shocked, losing a turn. Not to mention being able to cast water spells near a teammate to do damage to your enemies but put out the flames burning your partners shoulders to a crisp.

WORLD:
I haven't explored much yet but everything that I've seen so far has been put together very well. From item placement and decorations to broad scale placement of dungeons, changing weather and variety of landscapes.

NPCS:
I normally skip through that NPC's say in other games. The usual B.S. filler type material that just get irritating - BUT in this game I've become more involved in the storyline and actually enjoy the bickering within the group as well as the diversity in NPC personalities. A lot of effort was put in to making the storyline full with a hint of sassy.

SIDE NOTE:
I am a bit OCD and a horder in games... and sometimes it ruins games for me because I spend too much time collecting things. Example would be, in Skyrim and Fallout 3. I spent hours upon hours just making sure that 'THIS' chest in my home had only Elvish equipment or Laser weapons. While 'THIS' chest had only Ebony gear or Plasma weapons. I like to seperate things so that I can easily go back and look for things later, plus it becomes a center of pride for myself in game. Odd? Maybe. But this game allows me to feed my sorter desires by giving me back packs and a home" to store my people and valuables. I have backpacks for every different type of item and with the "pack mule" talent
date: its that much easier... I spent 2 out of my 10 hours just organizing and reoganizing. This may not be a selling point for some of you but for those who know what I'm saying... Yup

reviewText:
The devs put in a lot of effort to make this game, so it's only fair that I take some time to put down my thoughts about it in more than just a one-liner ^_^ Here we go...

Content
-------------------
There's lots of it. Don't get fooled by the 4 overworld maps like I did - Each one takes many many hours to complete. There's a good enemy variety, but most of it is fantasy standard: Orcs, spiders, skeletons, ... They can have some nice/surprising abilities though. You'll spend quite some time in your inventory comparing stats of the tons of items you find and trying out some crafting recipes. Completing every (side-)quest and doing almost everything D:OS has to offer took about 105 hrs on hard difficulty - It's a long game but doesn't overstay its welcome. You'll see everything on a single playthrough except for some alternate consequences of choices you make. They aren't significant enough to justify playing it again though. However, the different char progressions and party setups do. For example, I never tried a stealthy rogue approach and rarely used witchcraft. Also, I highly suggest keeping an eye on the mod scene as those guys made me enjoy rpgs up to 4 times as long as intended...

Combat
-------------------
It's turn-based - each turn, a character gets action points depending on his stats to spend on movement, attacks or using items and once you're done, another character or enemy gets his turn.
After using a spell/skill, there's a cooldown to prevent you (and your enemy) from using those high damage AoE spells every turn.
A very cool aspect of the combat system is, that many spells work together or with the environment in some way. See a puddle of water? Electrify it and everything standing in it. Enemies enjoying some toxic gas? Throw a fireball and make it explode around them. Dragon Age 1 did something like this, but D:OS takes it even further.
Of course enemies and yourself have resistances and immunities to elements, forcing you to adapt your strategy.

Balance/Difficulty
-------------------
In general, it's far more difficult than most modern rpgs and the only one since Dragon Age 1 that managed to kill me. Repeatedly :D Once you get used to how everything works, it's a lot easier than what you might expect though. In any case, the difficulty is too inconsistent - Early-game is quite hard because you have few good spells available, then in Luculla Forest and Hiberheim it gets a lot easier and then difficulty spikes again for a short time on the last map only to drop to zero near the end. Imho it SHOULD start fairly easy and then gradually get harder - I have yet to play a game that gets this right though (and it's probably impossible because difficulty is so subjective...) Except for one instance the game is not unfair - you always know exactly WHY the enemy wiped the floor with you.
I like that the game randomly throws some bosses in your face - Here
date: have a giant spider for no reason!" - and some of them like the Braccus Rex battle really require you to come up with a good tactic. The final boss was a big disappointment though and got boring quickly because you are so overpowered by then that it requires just time
recommended:
no effort.

Char progression/Skills
-------------------
You get 2 main chars + 2 additional ones you can hire either in the area Cyseal or in your "base". On lvl-up you spend points in the usual rpg stats (strength
hoursPlayed: intelligence
voteText: ...) and a variety of different skills (like elemental magic). Every now and then you get to pick a special
helpfulPercent:
powerful trait. You can develop your party however you want - there's nothing stopping you from making a fireball throwing warrior.

Story/Quests

reviewText:
I havent gotten super far into it so I cant speak for the narrative as a whole, but the line-writing is very good.

The actual gameplay I think is fantastic combat presents you with a great variety of tactical options, and you can get really creative with spell combos. Its turn-based, which has the downside of leaving me bored while I wait for enemies to act but the upside of giving me time to really think and plan.

Theres a multiplayer conversation system (which you can play both sides of if youre playing a SP game, or assign the second protagonist an AI personality to automatically choose their own lines) which is even better than SWTORs because it actually takes into account whether the protagonists agree or disagree with one another; my only criticism is the rock-paper-scissors method of decision resolution if you disagree (its also used as the persuasion minigame when trying to convince NPCs). So, very strong first impression. Id have more to say if Id completed it.

reviewText:
Pretty close to my ideal game. Similar to Temple of Elemental Evil but not burdened by a PnP mechanic system nor the desire to recreate a PnP module. Single player alone would be amazing, but the multiplayer through the campaign is fully supported and essentially plays out like all the good parts of a PnP session (down to internal party conflicts, if minimally) with all the benefits of being a CRPG. The combat system is incredibly deep but follows consistent rules and heavily rewards clever tactics, with huge emphasis on proper positioning and use of environment.

The game is also quite challenging, giving a reason to need good tactics. Crowd control is brutal, you will almost always be outnumbered and your enemies are not afraid to lock your party down if you mess up. A number of special encounters also introduce little gimmicks, ensuring major fights don't get completely repetitive.

On top of that, the game is fairly freeform within the constraints of a linear plot. Most side quests have alternative resolutions that can impact how other missions play out. The quests themselves are handled as journal entries rather than specific tasks and rewards exploration and proactive investigation.

The only real issues are that the very end game feels a bit rushed (that said, this is after 50+ hours of very high production quality campaign) and, arguably, balance issues (due to the emphasis on battlefield control, ranged and caster characters are extremely strong in comparison to melee). However, the balance is debatable and on the whole a lot more enjoyable due to the high differentation in the skillsets compared to a very tightly tuned skillset, and the ability of any character to essentially multiclass freely gives you lots of options if something isn't working out.

reviewText:
Haven't finished it but I'm over 70 hours in so I think I can write a fair review.

I was worried I'd be bad at this game but it was getting such great reviews I decided to buy it on sale.  Happy that I did.

You're eased into the game at the start, although the number of skills you have at your disposal is a little daunting.  After the initial intro however, you're on your own.  A lot of things are there for you to discover as you play the game.  This makes it a bit harder but it's done in a way that is fun.  And there's lots of that to be had.

The graphics in these well imagined environments are gorgeous, but you do need a hefty system for them.  I tried it with both 4 and then 8 gigs of RAM.  There's an enormous difference in performance despite my video card (770 GTX).

Story is very intriguing, but the game shines I think most in gameplay.  The number of skills/spells you can have is staggering and almost seems unfair to the enemies you'll face.  This is not a linear game, however I will say you'll be limited at times as to where you can go due to enemy level difference, which you can sometimes circumvent.  As an example I snuck through a whole canyon of higher level orcs and goblins to access a mine with my rogue, then teleported the rest of the party inside to continue.  This can be problematic however if you can't find enemies you can level up on.

This is a LONG game, and you can really tell that they put effort in refining it.  There are a lot of events that had me laughing out loud too; the developers have quite a sense of humor.

If you're a fan of the genre I wouldn't pass it up.

reviewText:
In summary: the perfect entrypoint for someone who wants to get into old-school, DnD style RPGs; especially late-to-the-party generation kids who enjoy the RPG genre.

It's not Game of Thrones, but I'm very happy with the idea of a game that can introduce me to the type of storytelling that doesn't patronize me with the instant gratification of the all too obvious maps, dialogue and waypoints combination we've become accustomed to in contemporary RPGs.

I feel like I missed the generation of DnD, Fallout 1/2, and Baldur's Gate; growing up on what I'd call almost mindless RPGs like Oblivion, Mass Effect, Dragon Age and Skyrim. Games that are incredibly fun, but require very little effort or attention to detail to complete; games that certainly show the hallmarks of an RPG, but lack the complete-formula and romance of the classic pen and paper dungeon crawler.

This game is a step in the right direction, and I look forward to giving Baldur's Gate another try after I've played through this 3 times or more.

reviewText:
This game is overall great.

Took me a moment to wrap my head around the concept that even though an area is accessible the enemies aren't necessarily beatable yet.  I had to recreate my characters 3 times to get what I felt like was a decent composition, but that was part of the fun since there's so much to choose from.  Of course part of the problem is you're setting a large amount of customization before you even see waht the world has to offer.

Sort of like Turn-based Diablo meets Dark Souls meets Baldur's Gate meets Dungeon Siege.

Lots of inventory management, lots of different things to customize, lots of challenging battles, lots of interesting combat situations.

For instance, if there is poison on the ground you can blow it up with fire, and you can then put oil on the fire to make a black smoke archers cannot see through.  You can make it rain and then chill someone in order to have a chance to freeze them.  You can use the rainwater to strengthen your electricity spells instead, etc etc etc.

Worth a shot if you're into the genre.  If you're a super casual player, I'm not sure if I can recommend or not.

Just a month ago have started to play Divine Divinity. Something of the best games I've ever played on par with Fallout1, Fallout 2 with great quests, decent lore/background and a rich value of quests and world interactions.

reviewText:
Haven't finished it but I'm over 70 hours in so I think I can write a fair review.

I was worried I'd be bad at this game but it was getting such great reviews I decided to buy it on sale.  Happy that I did.

You're eased into the game at the start, although the number of skills you have at your disposal is a little daunting.  After the initial intro however, you're on your own.  A lot of things are there for you to discover as you play the game.  This makes it a bit harder but it's done in a way that is fun.  And there's lots of that to be had.

The graphics in these well imagined environments are gorgeous, but you do need a hefty system for them.  I tried it with both 4 and then 8 gigs of RAM.  There's an enormous difference in performance despite my video card (770 GTX).

Story is very intriguing, but the game shines I think most in gameplay.  The number of skills/spells you can have is staggering and almost seems unfair to the enemies you'll face.  This is not a linear game, however I will say you'll be limited at times as to where you can go due to enemy level difference, which you can sometimes circumvent.  As an example I snuck through a whole canyon of higher level orcs and goblins to access a mine with my rogue, then teleported the rest of the party inside to continue.  This can be problematic however if you can't find enemies you can level up on.

This is a LONG game, and you can really tell that they put effort in refining it.  There are a lot of events that had me laughing out loud too; the developers have quite a sense of humor.

If you're a fan of the genre I wouldn't pass it up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Divinity:Original Sin feels like the updated child of Baldur's Gate. Design a character from the ground up, choosing skills, feats and spells or opt to take one of the predefined classes. Manage a party of up to four using the slick team controls, or play online multiplayer with each of your friends designing and controlling a character. Conversations with NPCs and between party members are deep and impactful, with each individual being able to act seperately or even adventure seperately if compromise cannot be reached. Combat is turn based, but the Action Point system feels fast and responsive.

The very best part of this game however is the extensive modability. I have not seen an editor this well done since Warcraft 3, and already parts of the commuinity are stepping up to make campaigns to rival those of Neverwinter Nights 2. So even if you are on the fence today, I urge you to keep an eye out for what can be done with the engine.

reviewText:
Understand that this game is its own world. It has its own rules and logic and not all of them are recognizable right away. At first, the game seems hard, and it almost is. It can be punishing to die, and frustrating to get stuck on a puzzle. Ultimately though, because this game is its own world, the reward for uncovering is great. There is so much freedom and independence in this game, it almost feels strange coming from a long line of games that hold your hand to the point it isnt exploration, its a tour. This game is not a guided tour. Youll need to reload quick saves here and there, and might even lose progress up to 30min of play or more because of a surprise encounter or trap.

But! This game is outstanding. All of the above points only help to realize and flesh out the world. The sense of achievement you get when figuring out a difficult puzzle or beating a tough encounter is huge. This game is great, and if you aren't playing it and have a tiny shred of interest, i'd reccomend it without hesitation. I could write a five page point by point on this game and how much it has going for it, but better you experience it.

reviewText:
Just a month ago have started to play Divine Divinity. Something of the best games I've ever played on par with Fallout1, Fallout 2 with great quests, decent lore/background and a rich value of quests and world interactions.

Divinity: Original Sin took most of the pros of it's predcessor (including some of the mechanics, game world lore etc.) while got somewhat adopted to the more modern requirements to the games that players tend to have now.

Absolutely recommend to everyone that likes dialogues, character customisation and a fair bit of role playing with the ability to choose (so that your choice does really change the outcome, although not the in main quest line).

But beware:
- This thing is pretty much addictive. Plan your time accordingly.
- Exploration part sometimes tends to become a burden - game has tons of random loot in all kinds of boxes, stashes and barrels.
- Battles are turn-based and sometimes take more then a hour and more then just a few save-loads to finish in your favour. If you are looking for some action in game - this one is not for you.

reviewText:
In summary: the perfect entrypoint for someone who wants to get into old-school, DnD style RPGs; especially late-to-the-party generation kids who enjoy the RPG genre.

It's not Game of Thrones, but I'm very happy with the idea of a game that can introduce me to the type of storytelling that doesn't patronize me with the instant gratification of the all too obvious maps, dialogue and waypoints combination we've become accustomed to in contemporary RPGs.

I feel like I missed the generation of DnD, Fallout 1/2, and Baldur's Gate; growing up on what I'd call almost mindless RPGs like Oblivion, Mass Effect, Dragon Age and Skyrim. Games that are incredibly fun, but require very little effort or attention to detail to complete; games that certainly show the hallmarks of an RPG, but lack the complete-formula and romance of the classic pen and paper dungeon crawler.

This game is a step in the right direction, and I look forward to giving Baldur's Gate another try after I've played through this 3 times or more.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is a Balder's Gate-esque roleplaying game where you are sent to uncover a mysterious killer in the town of Cyseal, but what you find has consequences which affect the entire world.

Divinity is a fantastic game. Absolutely amazing. It has been #1 on Steam since it's launch for a reason: it's incredibly good.

I spent 90 hours fully completing the game, and enjoyed it all.

Divinity is a roleplaying game in the truest sense. When you talk to someone, or learn a new bit of info, it gets added to your journal, but that's it. There's no quest objectives, no drive, it's up to you and you alone to figure out what to do. You wanna investigate the scene of a murder, okay, what do you do? Really, think about it, what's your first move? Then, you do it in-game!

There's no hand-holding, no hints or tips, it's pure logic and it's incredibly enjoyable and satisfying.

There are some bugs, but Larian have been releasing patches almost twice a week fixing the little odds and ends which cause issue. Throughout the entire 90 hours of play, I encountered only 1 bug I would consider annoying"

reviewText: Would it not be interesting if Path of Exile players had control over quests, bosses, loot, entire zones and instances, triggered scenarios, decisions to be made, active scripts, and unique items; among controlling the entire experience? That is Divinity: Original Sin. DOS could develop into a customizable Ultima Online experience which satisfies a desire of constant discovery, danger, and community. The single player campaign, played with up to four people, can last more than 100 hours. This serves as the tutorial for the game. Explore a new area with a kind stranger or get murdered and/or robbed of valuables. Develop strong friendships and create actual enemies. The community behind Divinity will create worlds and people in these persistent-like microcosms will survive between pact and brutality. Players familiar with Ultima VII will feel especially right at home as the game evolves into a rare style of exploration and adventure that has been missing for far too long.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a video and written impression of the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxTtm9l_AHw
Divinity takes PC turn based RPGs and modernize it with the shimmer and shine of today's graphical standards. Though the game looks fantastic, I would even go as far as saying one of the best in the genre, the core and mechanics stay true to it's source. The game is deep and will require dozens if not hundreds of hours from the player. If you are looking for a time sink, this one will do you just fine. The writing and story are equally as impressive as it's visuals. Characters are lively with humor and personality, and the narrative will draw you in with it's many incentives to role play.

Since the game is so large in scope, I found it to be slow at the start. Not just pacing, but also in understanding. It took me a few re-rolls before I made a game that I was happy with, and even then it took me roughly 3-4 hours before I moved away from the dialog heavy town, and into the more actiony bits. Of course my persistent demand to talk to every single towns folk before leaving may have contributed to more time than needed, and only serve as testimony in how engrossing the writing can be. Also keep in mind, you need to be able to enjoy reading... a lot. There is only limited voice acting and the majority of the game is told in written form.

Overall, the game is every thing I expected and more. It will probably go down as one of the great classics of our time.

Pros:
- Excellent visuals and overall presentation
- Deep mechanics
- HUGE game
- Lots of customization
- Great writing
- Classic return to form, for this style of RPG

Cons:
- Slow to start (potentially).
- Could prove too daunting for those who are short on free time.

So far I can honestly say that this game is a true successor of divine divinity and that's all we ever wanted the fans of divine divinity.

Many users are comparing this to baldurs gate 2...well guess what? This is not a successor of that game and it wasn't even on their plans either! This company is Larian not BioWare, so that comparison doesn't even make sense! If you want a baldurs gate 3 then complain to bioware...

The writing, the quests, how can you equip or use almost any items for something, pick-move-destroy almost everything, kill almost anyone, the open game (yes you can go anywhere but high level enemies will kill you in a second but it was like that even on divine divinity!)

So overall this game is fantastic maybe you will want to wait a little bit more before playing it because it's still a little buggy but they are patching the game very often but dont get me wrong, right now the game is playable, very much playable, it's not like a beta version if that's what you are thinking or someone said on the forum but like a I said little things here and there, but then again it's a big game with a lot of stuffs so it is to be expected.

All in all a 9/10 game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Divinity: Original Sin is quite worth the cost even in its current Alpha state. I won't focus on bugs here. That's what the forums are for.

The Turn Based combat uses Action Points to dictate how much you can do in a single turn. This means a single turn could consist of an item use, special skill, and maybe a normal attack. You can also end your turn early to AP to allow more actions per turn. This greatly affects how you approach each fight. Additionally, each fight has the potential to be a completely unique experience with interactive elements. See an oil barrel? Attack it and oil spills out. Got some flaming arrows or a fire spell? Set the oil on fire and burn your enemies. Got a Rain spell? Put the fire out with rain. Have electricity? Shock enemies standing in water to electrify the ground. Ice can also be used to create slippery areas that can knock enemies (and players alike) down. There are a number of possibilities using single elements or a combination.

Party members will actually interact with each other during certain conversations with NPCs. This leads into a back and forth between the characters you control. The outcome is a point increase in different social attributes. These help increase Luck, Charm, Leadership, Pickpocketing, etc. It's a pretty neat take on character development.

Inertacting with NPCs and the world is also quite enjoyable. Most NPCs can be talked to and bartered with. Objects like boxes and barrels can be looted, moved, or destroyed. Hanging hams or potion bottles sitting on tables that look like decoration can be stolen and used later in battles. Houses can be broken into and looted. NPCs can be attacked if you're feeling evil enough. Half of the time I have put in so far has been seeing what I can get away with around town and I will say there is a fair amount to do.

Crafting, though not fully implemented, it pretty wonderful as well. Simple combinations of herbs and potions can yield a variety of new potions. A wooden club and nails nets you a spiked club, a knife and pumpkin gets you a jack-o-latern helmet, etc. Considering the number of items I have found labeled Ingredient" I anticipate there being a number of recipes in future releases only adding to the things you can do.

DOS also looks fantastic. Textures

There is a lot to see and it's all quite enjoyable to look at.\n\nAll of this is packaged with Larian's off the wall humor seen in games like Divine Divinity or Beyond Divinity. I am incredibly excited to see this game when it's finished. Based on the devs hotfix coming out four days after the Alpha release

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR; You can surprise a lady having a bath and get yelled at. 11/10 will play for years.

I really wish other Early Access Games would be released with this much solid basic content to let you really feel like you have something to test that gives you an idea of what their end goal is. Larian has done it right. Yes there are some bugs and things that still need perfecting in the mechanics, but this is ALPHA and its purpose is for players to find those bugs and report them for fixing. The Alpha gives you the first town an some surrounding area to explore and do a few quests in, but it's a pretty HUGE area with a lot of content and even a couple of little easter eggs that give you a good insight into what the rest of the game will be like to play through. There's plenty of combat encounters with nasty things for you to play around with the turn based combat mechanics and leveling your characters. It's not an Alpha you'll burn through in an hour! I played for around 15 hours and still didn't finish everything or go everywhere. Hell, the recently released Might & Magic X is at final release only about a 25 hour game for the same price... And frankly I'm pretty angry I bought the Alpha for that one at this point considering how limp the final release is.

D:OS is for fans of Larian like myself, a long-anticipated game from a game developer with a history of quirky but addicting games and dedication to their playerbase. Divine Divinity (their first in this series) came out in 2002 and I bought it for myself for xmas that year and was instantly hooked. I had played Diablo so much I had actually worn out a couple of game CD's of it, but there'd been nothing since 1996 which had caught me quite the same till DivDiv came out, and I can honestly say if I put 500+ hours into Diablo, I must have over the years put 1000+ into DivDiv and have bought many copies of the game. I am actually working on another playthrough to keep myself occupied till D:OS comes out lol It's still to this day my favourite game.

Larian's creative, fresh and cheeky style never grows old and has a great balance of a light hearted comedic RPG with some silly elements, but also a very deep and complex serious story with a vast world of politics and lore beneath it. The NPC's are lively and memorable, your own character conversation choices are full of personality and life". I was very pleasently reminded of DivDiv when I played Dragon Age

I played for around 15 hours and still didn't finish everything or go everywhere. Hell, the recently released Might & Magic X is at final release only about a 25 hour game for the same price... And frankly I'm pretty angry I bought the Alpha for that one at this point considering how limp the final release is.

D:OS is for fans of Larian like myself, a long-anticipated game from a game developer with a history of quirky but addicting games and dedication to their playerbase. Divine Divinity (their first in this series) came out in 2002 and I bought it for myself for xmas that year and was instantly hooked. I had played Diablo so much I had actually worn out a couple of game CD's of it, but there'd been nothing since 1996 which had caught me quite the same till DivDiv came out, and I can honestly say if I put 500+ hours into Diablo, I must have over the years put 1000+ into DivDiv and have bought many copies of the game. I am actually working on another playthrough to keep myself occupied till D:OS comes out lol It's still to this day my favourite game.

Larian's creative, fresh and cheeky style never grows old and has a great balance of a light hearted comedic RPG with some silly elements, but also a very deep and complex serious story with a vast world of politics and lore beneath it. The NPC's are lively and memorable, your own character conversation choices are full of personality and life". I was very pleasently reminded of DivDiv when I played Dragon Age

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first memorable Top Down RPG was probably the Fallout series and in many ways it's left a lasting impression on what i like in my RPG's.  I absolutely fall in love with rich worlds, well crafted lore, unique NPCs, and a certain amount of freedom with character creation (both in gameplay and personality).  While their have been many pretenders to the throne to this old school theory of game development and the general meta-game has shifted toward action based RPG's Larian Studios has restored my faith with Divinity Original Sin.

I've been playing through the comabt and avoiding the story as much as possible but what accidental bits i've discovered and the combat has me very excited for the full release.  To say i've bought into the hype is a bit of an understatement.  I'm actively drinking the kool-aid at this point.

This is going to be one of those games you wake up on the weekend and make yourself a cup of coffee while playing co-op with one of your old gaming friends.  There will be pauses between dialogue choices as you decided how you want to respond and several minute long planning sessions on how to engage a tough fight (see the 4 elemental demon bosses early on.  We fought them at lvl 4 and won but it did take a little bit of planning).

I'll give a more solid review when the game is fully released as i've been reading that launch has been delayed for voice acting (MOTHER OF GOD, YES!) and the same company and actors from dragon commander are doing the voices.  For the uninformed, Dragon Commander has some very solid voice acting and helped sell the world and general atmosphere of the game.  I have complete faith that a return of the actors from Dragon Commander will be an incredible experience ontop of something i'm already looking forward to.  (i also have a schoolyard crush on the actress that did Ophelia's voice in Dragon Commander, Here's hoping she does voices for Original Sin too)

But my general reccomendation is to buy this game.  If you're a twitch gaming kind of guy then save your money for something more to your taste but if you like RPG's, stategy games, Pen/Paper DND, tactical turn-based combat, and any variations of those core game elements then this game is absolutely for you.

So far I can honestly say that this game is a true successor of divine divinity and that's all we ever wanted the fans of divine divinity.

reviewText:
I technically bought this game from concept on Kickstarter a few years ago as I loved the previous game Larian studios (the developer) had made including divine divinity and dragon commander series so I was interested in another game within that universe.


Old school RPG's seem to be rare delicacy in recent years so from what the guys had set out on the Kickstarter page and the guide of how the money would be spent I though why not give it a bash as their previous work that I had come across was good.


Took me roughly about 67 hours to complete the single player story which is pretty good in this day an age of 5 hour long corridor simulators.


Combat is turn based and turned out to be one of the best parts as different elements and abilities combine with each other which adds a certain level of strategy to each battle as u have to be careful not to zap or burn your own party accidently,
As an example if there is water on the ground and you cast a ice spell you could turn that water to ice and cause a surface your party and the enemy Ai could slip and fall over on.


Music is brilliant really adds to the atmosphere of the zone you are in at the time.


The story starts of as a simple investigation about a murder but develops into a more sinister plot that threatens the world. The story is a bit hit and miss but it has its moments and has plenty of the good old Larian studios humour mixed in.


The world is really immersive and beautifully designed props to the art team loads of hidden items treasure secret caves underground caverns so if you like exploring you will love the adventure you will have in this game and the game has plenty of side quests that will get you out there in the world.


Now while I appreciate the way the devs did the navigation and quest layouts I can see some people maybe having a bit of trouble finding their way around initially, the game does sort of throw you in the deep end and if you have never played games such as Baldurs Gate or Neverwinter it could be a bit overwhelming. This game doesn't have a press a button to see where you need to go or a massive arrow pointing to the quest objective you have to take the time to read the quests and listen to what the NPCs tell you in the game or you will find yourself lost.


The start of the game is a bit slow and I could see some people getting bored but stick with it once you get out of the first town and get exploring the game really picks up and gets its hooks into you  :)

It's a yes from me on this one guys if you  love adventure and exploring beautifully crafted worlds get this one bought ASAP.

P.s no I am not in the mood for cheese -_-

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is a Balder's Gate-esque roleplaying game where you are sent to uncover a mysterious killer in the town of Cyseal, but what you find has consequences which affect the entire world.

Divinity is a fantastic game. Absolutely amazing. It has been #1 on Steam since it's launch for a reason: it's incredibly good.

I spent 90 hours fully completing the game, and enjoyed it all.

Divinity is a roleplaying game in the truest sense. When you talk to someone, or learn a new bit of info, it gets added to your journal, but that's it. There's no quest objectives, no drive, it's up to you and you alone to figure out what to do. You wanna investigate the scene of a murder, okay, what do you do? Really, think about it, what's your first move? Then, you do it in-game!

There's no hand-holding, no hints or tips, it's pure logic and it's incredibly enjoyable and satisfying.

There are some bugs, but Larian have been releasing patches almost twice a week fixing the little odds and ends which cause issue. Throughout the entire 90 hours of play, I encountered only 1 bug I would consider annoying"

reviewText: Would it not be interesting if Path of Exile players had control over quests, bosses, loot, entire zones and instances, triggered scenarios, decisions to be made, active scripts, and unique items; among controlling the entire experience? That is Divinity: Original Sin. DOS could develop into a customizable Ultima Online experience which satisfies a desire of constant discovery, danger, and community. The single player campaign, played with up to four people, can last more than 100 hours. This serves as the tutorial for the game. Explore a new area with a kind stranger or get murdered and/or robbed of valuables. Develop strong friendships and create actual enemies. The community behind Divinity will create worlds and people in these persistent-like microcosms will survive between pact and brutality. Players familiar with Ultima VII will feel especially right at home as the game evolves into a rare style of exploration and adventure that has been missing for far too long.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a video and written impression of the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxTtm9l_AHw
Divinity takes PC turn based RPGs and modernize it with the shimmer and shine of today's graphical standards. Though the game looks fantastic, I would even go as far as saying one of the best in the genre, the core and mechanics stay true to it's source. The game is deep and will require dozens if not hundreds of hours from the player. If you are looking for a time sink, this one will do you just fine. The writing and story are equally as impressive as it's visuals. Characters are lively with humor and personality, and the narrative will draw you in with it's many incentives to role play.

Since the game is so large in scope, I found it to be slow at the start. Not just pacing, but also in understanding. It took me a few re-rolls before I made a game that I was happy with, and even then it took me roughly 3-4 hours before I moved away from the dialog heavy town, and into the more actiony bits. Of course my persistent demand to talk to every single towns folk before leaving may have contributed to more time than needed, and only serve as testimony in how engrossing the writing can be. Also keep in mind, you need to be able to enjoy reading... a lot. There is only limited voice acting and the majority of the game is told in written form.

Overall, the game is every thing I expected and more. It will probably go down as one of the great classics of our time.

Pros:
- Excellent visuals and overall presentation
- Deep mechanics
- HUGE game
- Lots of customization
- Great writing
- Classic return to form, for this style of RPG

Cons:
- Slow to start (potentially).
- Could prove too daunting for those who are short on free time.

reviewText:
In short: An extremely good classical RPG.

For the elders:
I wouldn't say it's on par with Baldur's Gate 2 or Torment, but yet it's not far behind either. It will surely bring you good memories. For younglings: This is the best game for you to introduce you to a great game type which was left aside for a good while. If you like this one, you're on a great path, which will include (in any order) Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Arcanum, the two first Fallouts, and Planescape Torment (My all time favorite).
It might be harder than your average game, but like every game (not just video games), overcoming the difficulty is proportionnaly rewarding.

9/10 A must buy.

reviewText:
***MILD SPOILERS FOR SERIES FANS! YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!***

If you're a fan of the original Divine Divinity (or the series as a whole), you will not be disapointed with OS. Staple mechanics are here (lock picking, pyramid teleporters, crafting food and potions by collecting ingredients out in the world), some of which are recognisably the classic Div Div systems (the skill-up system is pleasingly familiar, whilst also being greatly expanded), and some of which are fresh new additions.

Perhaps best of all for series fans, the lore, setting and characters are all intact. The Legion are around in their various garrisons and forts, Arhu is on-hand to dispense wisdom and advice, and, of course, the Source is present and correct (or  rather, corrupt).

Beyond Div's simultaneous 2 character system works even better in OS. In fact, it's chalk and cheese, and any painful memories you may have of that game's controls, or the notorious Fergus will be wiped away. Your group can be split up and easily managed just by dragging the portraits around, so no worries there.

I never thought isometric RPGs could get better than Div Div, but OS takes the crown.

reviewText:
This game can be very difficult at first. The world and gameplay are very detailed, and the game doesn't really act like most games in helping you along. This learning curve can be very intimidating when you first start playing, and actually had me put the game down after a few hours, thinking I would never pick it back up. Boy am I glad I did. All of those reasons that make it so difficult to start make it so rewarding once you can some momentum.

One of my favorite all time games is Baldur's Gate 2. That game was so professionally crafted, and although it was an open-world RGP on the surface, it doubled as a complex strategy game. Unlike most games of today, the encounters were not levelled. That meant you could walk into an encounter with enemies at a much higher level than your character. Of course, you would probably be eviscerated in your attempt to just get out alive. Then after you reloaded your game, you would be obsessed at beating that challenge. You would try different spells, buy different equipment, try sneaking and backstabbing, different spells and scrolls, you would do anything possible to win. The game was amazingly open to your creative solutions, and once you finally found a strategy that looked like it worked, you would be exhilarated. I loved that about that game more than anything. While I have loved games like Skyrim since then, I have still never experienced anything quite like that since.

Divinity: Original Sin may be the most worthy successor to Baldurs Gate 2 I have seen. The RPG elements are different. It takes more of an Elder Scrolls type style, where you can choose to start from base classes, but leveling up doesn't have class restrictions. You can start as a thief, then start learning spells. You can be an archer that knows water based spells, or a assassin that knows witchcraft. its more closer to the spirit of the 4th edition of D&D than advanced dungeons and dragons. Overall I think that works well. There are many choices to make that create nuanced changes to your gameplay.

The setting and world is very detailed, but feels like a much smaller scale than Baldur's Gate 2. Though you can enter every building and talk and trade with every character.

The game really excels in its combat. Everything works together and can be used strategically. You can put out fires with a Rain spell, you can light oil on fire to burn your enemies. You can shock everyone standing in a pool of water, you can blow up poison gas. You get up to four party members, and can make each of their skills compliment each other. My one buddy will often lay an oil slick on the ground to have my thief ignite with his flame spells(yes my thief is a pyrotechnic wizard). My actual wizard will often teleport an enemy close to my buddy's bruiser warrior character for quick dispatchment. There are a million and one different ways to approach a battle and we often lose miserably on a first encounter, only to eventually succeed after careful planning. There aren't many encounters you can really take for granted. There are probably less enemy encounters than in other games, but each one is hard fought and feels dynamic. Essentially, this is as far from a hack and slash game you can possibly have.

In typical D:OS fashion, the crafting/inventory/item collection aspects are richly detailed and not explicitly explained. Its indicative of every aspect of the game. Most of the time it feels like a developer is trying to point out ever single part of their game in an effort to demonstrate how much time it took to create it. Larian Studios is so absurdly casual about crafting one the most dense games in decades. We were basically ignoring cracting entirely until my partner found a  Guidebook[www.divinityoriginalsin.com] online. I thought all that stuff we were picking up was just meaningless stuff to sell. Needless to say, we are pretty excited to jump back into the game and try some of that stuff out.

I don't have many complaints about the game, but I have some differences of opinions. Mainly, I wish that this was 4 player, considering that you can have 4 party members. Also, we my friend hosts our game, and the save files aren't accessible to me at all. I don't really own the characters I play with, its like he just grants me control while we play together. We also end up fighting over chests a little more than I like. Some recent games like Deathtrap brought some appreciated sharing of treasure. In D:OS, we tend to greedily race to the dropped loot after a battle and walk into traps looking for chests.

Take Divine Divinity world. Add party members. Add turn-based combat. That's something similar to what it plays like. If you're looking for an easy going, streamlined experience where you always know where you're going, and what you need to do, then stay away. You're probably not going to like it.

One last note, if you're not a fan of a little monty python/terry pratchet humour in your games.. you're also going to have issues.

But from an old-school rpg fan, this is a damn treat and I'm enjoying the heck of it.

reviewText: Once upon a time, they used to make role playing games for computers.   They weren't strategy/action/shooter hybrids. They weren't massively multiplayer.  They were just RPGs -- no hypens, no prefixes.  They had titles like Ultima, Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Fallout (1 & 2), Neverwinter Nights, Arcanum, Dragon Age: Origins.  These were awesome games and a lot of people loved them, but game publishers decided that they weren't generating enough revenue so they stopped making them.\n\nLarian has successfully revived a dead genre and updated it in a meaningful way.  And they somehow managed it without a publisher and the compromises that come along with them.  I could list the reasons why I love this game, but I really want to get back to playing.  So all I'll say is this:  if you've ever enjoyed a real computer RPG, get this game.  If you're sick of gear grinding, F2P schemes, and consolization, buy this game.  Don't wait for a sale.  Just click the button and buy it.  You can thank me later.

reviewText:
Take Divine Divinity world. Add party members. Add turn-based combat. That's something similar to what it plays like. If you're looking for an easy going, streamlined experience where you always know where you're going, and what you need to do, then stay away. You're probably not going to like it.

If however, you like old school rpgs like Ultima 7/Morrowind (Not the rest of the series, just Morrowind with it's no quest markers and having to read quest logs/dialogue to figure out what you've got to do) then this is going to be a blast for you.

So far.. I'd really probably call it, a modern day Ultima 7 without the awful combat system they switched to and reviving the Ultima 6 turn-based system.. but also modernized.

One last note, if you're not a fan of a little monty python/terry pratchet humour in your games.. you're also going to have issues.

But from an old-school rpg fan, this is a damn treat and I'm enjoying the heck of it.

reviewText:
YAY's:
- Great combat mechanics; emphasis on abilities and terrain/objects interaction.
- Beautiful graphics engine; vivid colors and nice particle effects.
- Good lengthy storyline/dialog with a quirky sense of humor.
- Excellent music, sound effects, and character voice-overs.
- Hot-join 2-player coop; party members can be reassigned.
- Dev studio that listens to the community and quickly patches.
- Toolkit to develop your own mods.
- Very limited player hand-holding (challenging enemies, no quest markers, no auto-crafting); may be a NAY for some?

NAY's:
- Interface (inventory management, spell bar, party grouping) is clunky.
- Character and weapon/armor aesthetics are lacking in variety.
- Requires a larger amount of customizable hotkeys.

Divinity: Original Sin is a love letter to earlier cRPGs like Ultima 7 or Baldur's Gate. Player characters are completely customizable, not pigeon-holed to a specific class. You can build whatever combination you desire, though some builds may be more effective than others. Combat is turn-based and individual battles may take as long as 20 minutes to finish. Battles are tough as you will typically be outnumbered. However, taking time to learn the mechanics is very rewarding and you will finish each battle feeling like a tactical genius. The game can be played single-player but the coop experience is where the game really shines. A friend can join your game at any point and control any character(s) that you assign to him/her. Larian Studios have been really stellar in quickly releasing patches and hotfixes post-release. This developer deserves your money. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Now that the game is released I can share my thoughts and experience with it and hopefully help someone make the choice if this game is for them or not.

I bought the game during its early access stage and completed the first portion it had (25% of the total game) for two times, then fiddled with it after each major update and I have to say that the game has evolved quite nicely, much better than I thought it would be.

The final version is great and works. I have heard of people experiencing some problems (or finding bugs), I've yet to find anything however so I won't say that its bug free or otherwise.

But how is the game itself? First of all, this is not your standard RPG like Diablo or Skyrim, its much more tactical. Think back to games like Dungeon Siege 1 where you had a party and each battle depended on the action you told each member to take, it depends on how you approach the battle and how well prepared you are.

At the same time the game does not hold your hands at all. You have a quest book which gives you information about what you need to do but most of the time it won't tell you where to go directly. It will however give you hints and its up to you to find out how you can complete the quest. This is much more refreshing since it opens up the world a lot, it makes you think and revisit people and places to get more clues and ultimately complete the quest. Overall, once the quest is completed it feels so much more rewarding.

The game is also pretty much open world. Its not as open world as Skyrim for example but its so much more than Diablo, meaning that its not a linear experience of going to point B from point A but at the same time those points exist. Its up to you how you get from one point to another and especially when you go. No one said you can't go from point A to point G from the get go, just be ready to face some strong opponents on your way.

The NPC's in the game (friendly) are also very alive, they won't just sit idle while you steal from them, or rob their house. You can steal everything you want, just don't expect them to sit quietly and watch you take it all away. First they will stop you, then they will call the quards which in turn will land you in jail (if you do not stop stealing). But that doesn't mean the game forbids you from being an  to the world. As long as no one sees you, steal as much as you like (since its so damn rewarding).

Finally, the combat. Like I said in a previous paragraph, its a call back to the older games. The combat is turn based. You and your enemies take turns on hitting each other. You have a set about of Action points (AP) that you can use to do various things like moving, attacking, healing and so on. Once you run out of AP its time to end your turn and let the enemy do his thing.

Because of this turn based system the game feels much more fresh and at the same time much more harder (which is very good for this title). One mistake might cost you the lives of a team member or your own (thankfully you can revive them as long as you have a ressurection scroll). Play your cards right and you will win battles with ease...you just need to pay close attention and think before acting.

I personally recommend the game to RPG fans, especially those that loved the games of old and even more to the new people that haven't had the chance to try one of the old games due to various reasons.

reviewText:
I have never played any of this series at all so I'm giving this review without the past tinting it in good or bad way for those that might not know anything about the game.  So I will give you with the bit I've played my first impressions with what I think is good and bad.

Since I got it I haven't been able to get out of it... in a good way.  I'm totally addicted and found the game that suits me to the max.  This is turn based, so it gives me time to think without pressure yet still sitting on the edge of my seat at the fight.

It kind of threw me in the beginning though on character creation because I didn't know it was a duo... I was quite perplexed when I had to create two and customize them. (again I've never played any of the earlier ones so not even sure if that is how they worked in those)  But the whole two character thing had be curious right off the bat.  I figured it was basicly like a skyrim of a different flavor, story, etc etc.  But it isn't and it is!  For me, it's perfect.  It guides you along at the beginning yet gives you freedom to experiment and explore to start you out.  Perfectly balanced in my opinion for a brand new person.  They are great at the queues you need to not salp you in the face eyt pop up at the perfect time with suggestions.  They aren't obnoxious at all, but definitely letting you know about a new feature.

I think it is an amazing and creative touch about the dialogs you have that affect the game between your two characters that you choose how it goes.  There are different options.   They really thought out of the box on this one.  I'm an animator for the film TV and gaming industries and not much impresses me. But this one did.

the only negative thing I can say about it is the camera.  though it's not hard to get the hang at all on rotating it, they put a limit on it severely so you have to zoom in to see through walls at times, which is a feature of the game, not a bug.  It just messes up my immersion a wee bit, but i'm sure I will get used to it soon enough.

I just love the barter / selling / buying system a LOT.  items are as good as gold and visa versa.  it took me a couple times to realize I could switch between the characters in the same selling / bartering menu, but it's something that isn't hidden at all either.

I could go on and on about it but in a nut shell, it's just amazing and I'm totally addicted and that is a huge feat to do with my line of work.

Create an awesome day and kudos to the awesome creativity to the devs.  it is totally worth the price!

~ ish

Early Access Review

Want the ultimate RPG that allows you to do anything? feel like killing everyone? do it! Feel like stealing? Go ahead!

Original Sin Is a turned based RPG that you can play along with a friend with who controls the other character. Depending on how you interact with each other the two characters could hate each other, be best friends. or even...lovers (>'.')> <('.'<).

Currently in Early Access they let you play about 15hrs worth of content The devs say that the game in total with have 50 hours of gameplay. buy right now you also get the games Divine Divinity and Beyond Divinity.

The crafting in this game is very entertaining, if you want to make a pizza you have to have flour, water, tomatoes, and a hammer. Want to make a awesome club? get a branch and cover it with nails.

For a Early Access this fun and bug free I have no choice but to recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Real-time exploration combined with turn-based combat that is intuitive enough not to be a hassle every time you get into a fight. So far, this alpha build is already a good representation of what I expect from an RPG, having played games such as Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and other Black Isle games in the day.  This game, to me, is a modern adaptation, with mechanics, of the RPG-style game I played back then.  The option to discuss amongst the party and shape the personalities of the characters is a great feature to enhance the immersion.  I hope they'll take this a step further and open/close party member choices based on your party's personalities.

Options are limited in the Alpha, which is understandable. Still, I'll have to agree that this game is now near the top of my most wanted releases for this year and in my opinion already worth a recommendation. If you're a fan of RPG's, buy this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just how badly has modern game design softened your ability to be engaged in whats really going on in the story? The odds are quite a bit and this game will really show that. It's pretty refreshing to not have a quest marker, GPS tracker, arrow guidance or any quest helpers other then a detailed journal and common directional sense. It's actually funny how simple tasks without these crutches can now cause confusion and maybe embarassment or frustration.

Divinity Original Sin will allow you to once again be actually mentally engaged in the game in order to do progression rather then drudging through it like a undead. Speaking of undead there are plenty of them as the Soure Hunter you are you will be battling a lot of them. With very rich detail, an enthralling soundtrack and turn based combat, Divinity Original Sin will satisfy any real RPG fan.

reviewText:
This was my first PC RPG, so my review is without any nostalgia for this type of gameplay. And I loved the game. It wasn't perfect -- at times some things enfuriated me (backstabbing related usually), but overall it was amazing. I was obsessed. I still am.

The good:
1. The battle system is great. There's a lot to think about and reason to pay careful attention to what enemies are doing on their turn. The game can be very hard, so optimizing your moves and performing smart combinations matter.  Magic spells can interact with each other in really rad ways.
2. There are a lot of ways to complete quests, but it is still challenging to complete them.
3. Non-combat skills feel very important! Crafting, being able to talk to animals, teleportation -- all of these and more can help a lot.  With a high enough pickpocket talent you can steal from anybody in the game (who has items to trade, such as all shop keepers).
4. SO MUCH TO DO in every town! It really encourages exploration and does a good job of rewarding you.
5. Side stories and quests can be very interesting and funny.
6. The coop is well implemented. There are fun dialogs you can argue with your partner in. And it makes exploring towns go much faster when you split up.

The bad:
1. I've heard people say the UI for this game is good. It's not. This must be a compared to other PC RPGS" thing.  Your inventory will be a mess without enough good options for organization. Crafting can be a real pain because of this. Dragging an item through your inventory page by page is annoying. You can look at "only ingredients" in your inventory
date: but this doesn't help when you need to combine an ingredient with a weapon. I got around this by dragging things into pouches for crafting.\n2. The learning curve is a bit rough

reviewText: First, to the developers, a heartfelt thank you. Probably my first computer gaming experience was Ultima VII. I never finished it. It was too long, I was too young, and it was too hard to get games to run in the first place back then (memory managers? who remembers that crap?). It has, in the rouchly 25 years of gaming since then, been my white whale. I think about it constantly and long to play it again and finally finish it.\n\nDivinity: Original Sin captures so much of what made that game great to me, and so much of what simply doesn't exist in gaming today. It shines creatively, both in a refreshing take on stats/classes/skills/etc, as well as the story. I personally found the graphics to be very good as well. Art is a purely subjective thing to discuss, and I won't say that this game is for everyone. But I will say, if you want a deep role playing experience, turn-based combat, and a pool of nostalgia deep enough to drown in, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
It's been a long time since I've played an old school RPG of this quality. I highly recommend it to RPG fans! Here is my breakdown:

THINGS THIS GAME DOES RIGHT

Customization - Instead of setting the length and thickness of your character's nose, you get options that matter, like choosing skills, talents, and stats which add up to make your own custom class. Of course, you can pick from a default list and build it however you want if you prefer. This is customization done right.

Difficulty - This game will kill you. It's not Dark Souls hard, but it's hard enough to give you a sense of satisfcation when overcomingits challenges.

Non-linearity - Aspects of this game are non-linear. Ultimately it does have a linear narrative, but you can almost completely freely explore the world. You're limited mostly by your level, which is the main barrier limiting progression.

Grinding - Most RPGs allow you (or force you) to gain excessive amounts of experience to out-level the game's content. That is the fundamental principle of the JRPG. This game only gives you enough experience to survive the next challenge which ensures that the difficulty of the game is more fine tuned and harder to trivialize.

Puzzles - Not everything is explicitly a puzzle. Sometimes advancing the story is a puzzle in itself (like the old adventure games). Sometimes a combat has puzzle elements. Sometimes it's just a room full of traps. Either way, there's almost always a problem to figure out.

THINGS YOU MAY OR MAY NOT LIKE

Speed of Play - This is a slow methodical game best spent enjoyed at a leisurely pace. The turn based combat, sprawling maps, and slower paced movement speed means that it'll take hours to progress through what some may consider a small amount of content. For the perceptive and the patient, though, that content has a lot to offer.

Tone - It's a fairly straight forward fantasy setting. It's fun, whimsical, and self aware at times. It doesn't get overly dark nor overly comical. It's not too geneteric or creative. It serves primarily as a backdrop for the gameplay.

Co-op Dialogue - You can do rock-paper-scissors to overcome disagreements. What you choose impacts your stats in small ways. Min-maxers beware. Everyone else; have fun.

Random Loot - This has pros and cons. On the one hand, each playthrough is different. On the otherhand, a lot of loot sucks. It's debatable whether or not random loot works in a game with a limited pool of enemies.

Nietzsche - He can join your party. It's pretty neat if you're in to that sort of thing. The devs didn't actually name him Nietzsche, but you'll figure it out if you went through that phase in your teen years.

THINGS YOU PROBABLY WONT LIKE

Oops - It can be easy to make it hard or impossible to progress in the game by killing an NPC, letting them get killed, or just  them off enough. Same goes for accidently clicking on an object or walking into a room that causes the entire town to aggro on you. Save often.

Bugs - There's still quite a number of bugs, but they are very quickly being addressed. Still, be warned. Save often.
