reviewText:
I won't go into some long summary of the game. Watch the videos and read the info to find out what the game is about.

Pros:

Depth - The game has a vast amount of creativity behind it, and you just feel like you're playing a very deep game the moment you start. The fact that your companions interact with each other is brilliant and adds a nice Role play element for those who want it, or a chance to  around with a buddy's character for those that want to laugh. Each quest feels and plays differently than the next, and there are some quests in this game that just surprise you with how... different they are to the norm.

Combat - While I'm not the biggest turn-based fan, I heavily enjoy the combat sequences of this. Everything looks and sounds dramatic, and the risk of death is high. Even if you're on easy, if you don't have the right class pairings, you'll get smoked and there's no coming back from the dead spare a ressurection scroll (they're pretty pricey too). Thus far I'm only level 7 or 8 but I have more than a toolbar of spells, and each spell has a unique spin to it (I'm a Wizard or something if it wasn't obvious) from the silly teleport which moves the enemy from their location to another location several feet in the air causing massive damage from falling (and to anyone you put them near - definitely a strategic spell if done right) to an AoE boulder which throws poison on the ground for added damage. Don't forget my Ice Elemental for a free tank that you don't have to worry about it dying. However, be wary of boss battles. They are HARD

General Gameplay - Combat is one thing, but how do you play the rest of the time? Well, you are given a lot of freedom with what you do. That barrel that you think is silly? Move it elsewhere, or shoot an ice ball at it. That door that is locked? Pickpocket the owner for the key, or shoot an ice ball at it. Some shop keeper has some nice plates on display? Turn into a barrel with sneak mode and steal them away, but don't shoot ice balls at them because shop keepers don't like their stuff getting ice balled. I have a lot of fun just running around a village because I can do whatever I want and the game isn't needlessly punishing for shooting ice balls at things. Just don't hit anyone and don't steal their stuff in front of them and you won't normally get the guards (who are very strong).

Settings - While the raw graphics are subpar, the actual look of the game is colorful and fun. In the first few hours of the game I've gone from a placcid" beach

reviewText: This game is honestly... I... well, I can't really put it into words. Many people compare this to old-school RPGs like Neverwinter Nights, Baldur's Gate, and Ultima, and while I can honestly say I see the homage quite clearly, D:OS introduces many new concepts too. Co-op works seamlessly and flawlessly, the editor is great, and I can't wait to see what modders do with this game. My only main complaint about the game is the inventory system - it's a little clunky and hard to navigate at times, especially when you have a lot of items. The writing is clever and humorous, and I just found myself reading books and immersing myself in the world for hours on end - and I continue to do so as I play through the game.\n\nSo, how do you know if this game is for you? Honestly, if you've enjoyed any old-school isometric RPGs in the past (or currently), chances are that you'll enjoy this game. For a newcomer to the genre of CRPGs? Watch a couple videos, if you have friends who personally like the game, shoot them a message and ask them why it's great. I also realize it's a pretty hefty price tag, but I honestly think it's worth it - especially with all that comes shipped with the game.

reviewText:
A very solid game overall - a must-buy if you're a fan of old-school cRPGs.

The turn-based combat system is extremely deep and (especially in co-op mode) seems to help in making the combat not feel like a chore. It does have issues: often times it'll be hard to see where the edges of ground effects (fire, poison, etc.) are, especially if they're covered by grass. This has resulted in my characters taking unnecessary damage more times than I can count. Often times your character's vision will also be blocked for no reason, which can be frustrating. However, these issues are only minor and I expect they will be patched out in the near future.

The story is engaging and the quests are mostly interesting, but unfortunately (or fortunately if you're like me) there's barely any voice acting. That is forgivable, though, as the game has a gigantic amount of dialogue. If you like reading, just buy the game already!

One additional point I must bring up is the fact that the game starts off in a slow-ish manner. My friend and I were not very impressed by the combat system at the very beginning of the game, but it gets SO MUCH better after a few hours once you start getting more and more abilities to play around with.

To summarize: the game is very good, but not perfect. 100% recommended if you're into cRPGs, otherwise you might want to read around a bit more to make sure that the game is for you.

reviewText:
So many of the younger persons have been so spoiled growing up playing nothing but Diablo-like click fests, that they have no patience for a well thought out and deeper RPG experience.

Divinity: Original Sin, is throwback to the golden era of the cRPG. The age before Diablo's success spawned a new type of RPG with the most important element removed or given a back seat - THE STORY! Not to mention a watered down version of RPG combat - the button mash.

This game is nostalgic. It leaves me with a good feeling just thinking about returning to the game, and experiencing it with the attention and thought that it was designed for. There is great attention to detail, the writing is excellent and humor a fun diversion, and the combat forces you to think instead of like pointing at a group of monsters and clicking them to death.

This is what a real RPG game is all about! The developers did an excellent job with this.

reviewText:
Amazing game, I was glued to my screen the first few days after I bought this game.

Music: original, incredible, love the main theme.
Graphics: A lot better than you would expect from an indie game, though it warmed up my GPU faster than I would have expected.
Gameplay: Love the storyline, lots of sidequests, choices, free world, the only downside is everyonce in a while the entire progress of a quest hinges on you finding one button. Some quests had a very original way of solving them. I was stumped quite a few times, sometimes even hours on a puzzle, but when you solve them, it is extremely satisfactory. Using a walkthrough will reduce your enjoyment of this game a lot. As they hint themselves though: unless you are the most careful player in the world, save often.
Bugs: Encountered 1 bug in my entire playthrough. It was annoying, but since the game has 10 autosaves standard(up to 25), it was pretty easy to just load one, which fixed the situation.

Overall: Definitely in my top 10 list of Steam games I have ever played. If you are a D&D/pathfinder/.. player, you will love the open world, choices, consequences. 9/10

reviewText: Divinity: Original Sin is a refreshing reminder of the glory days of Infinity Engine RPGs, without all the problems that came forth. It might seem like a nostalgia trip, but it is actually a great game in and of itself, with complex and challenging combat, an in-depth crafting system, and plenty of character customization and dialogue to keep the most hardcore RPG players intrigued. There are also plenty of puzzles, many of which require some deep thinking, and some that are easy, and some that are well... a bit vague to say the least. That is actually one of the few problems that I have with this game, are the puzzles. I'm not the most patient person to begin with, but after Googling the answers to some of the puzzles I ask myself, how was I supposed to know that? And some of the puzzles are just searching for tiny  buttons that you need perception to find or something. Another fault I have in the game were the bugs. My playthrough had quite a few bugs that some would consider game-breaking, but I found a way around them and I did end up completing the game. Those are just a few faults, but there are more than enough positives to make up for it. Overall, a 9/10.

I didn't hear of this game until shortly before its release, but when I saw it in the Steam Sale and watched some gameplay videos of it I was instantly interested in it. An old-school RPG with turn-based combat, a well thought-through spell system (poison + fire = explosion, water/blood + electricity = stun, hitting puddles with fireballs makes them steam clouds, steam clouds + electricity = stun clouds and much, much more) and a huge, very detailed world with many secrets to discover make this game the best game I have played this year so far. reviewText:
Review @ 100 hours and level 18.

<tl;dr>
Despite having a few flaws this game is one of the most engaging for a long time, and worth the full asking price - don't wait for a sale, get it now!
</tl;dr>

My wife and I play this in LAN co-op mode, we bought this pre-release as we are fans of the genre but did not start playing until a few weeks after release to avoid the inevitable patch-aggrevation.

To gauge whether you have a similar taste to us, we loved:
- Baldur's Gate
- Neverwinter Nights
- Ultima series
- Sacred 1 & 2
- Diablo 1 & 2
- Titan Quest
- Eye of the Beholder
- old-school Sierra Online & Lucasarts games

After 200 collective hours of playing, we have not had a single crash (platform is Windows 8.1 x64) - this is noteworthy for modern games I think.

The things we like most about the game:
- the humour (at times subtle and possibly for older players, however)
- the camera style (not first-person or over-the-shoulder)
- the quests are not spoon-fed
- you are free to develop your characters as you want (no forced classes)
- ALT-tabbing works flawlessly and quickly

Things which have frustrated us at times, but not enough to dissuade from recommending the game:
- mis-clicking during combat due to animation of a mob
- the inventory UI does not feel polished (e.g. after dragging an item out of a container, clicking anywhere will be interpreted as a location for the character to move to)

For the NPC dialogues we can look at whichever screen we need to, but I can imagine the passive player in a co-op game might feel a little lost or left out if not in the same room as the active player.

We have had 1 quest which required a manual hack of a savegame to complete due to it disappearing entirely after selecting we'll talk about this later" - luckily a quick Google showed us what to hex-edit trivially to reset the quest/NPC status.

We have had no issues with performance
date: but our systems are not low-spec and not overclocked or bogged down with background processes - certainly no loading screens measured in minutes.\n\nIt is good to know that the game uses 1 core 100% all the time
recommended: so having at least a quad core CPU is advisable
hoursPlayed: as well as plenty of RAM

reviewText:
Ok... This is a bold statement... and shouldn't be taken lightly. Divinity: Original Sin is the BEST RPG I've ever played. Nothing can touch it. It's also my GOTY, hands down.

Rarely does a developer put so much of their love and affection into a game. Larian have, and by doing so, they've changed the game, maybe even the rulebook for every RPG that follows. This is the new benchmark, probably for any genre.

Even if you don't like RPGs, D:OS will have something for you. Even if you're a casual gamer, it's so well paced, you could hop in for just half an hour at a time. But you wont.

You'll be drawn into a beautiful, complex and vibrant world of adventure, mystery and more importantly FUN.

D:OS won't hold your hand, or assume you're stupid. You can do ANYTHING from the get go. GO anywhere.

This freedom isn't just limited to what you can do, it's how you do it.

You're offered choices constantly, be it through clever dialogues with NPC's or gameplay itself. The game will know what you've done, who knows about it, and who it will effect and adjust itself accordingly.

I'm not going to offer any spoilers here past the first hour. That would be morally bankrupt. The beauty of this game, is discovering it for yourself.

D:OS doesn't stop you from doing what you want. You can treat people how you want, do quests any way you want and shape the story any way you want. This is role playing at it's finest. Actually *Playing a Role*. Want to be the bad guy with a penchant for stealing fine art from inns? Go ahead, or maybe you want to be the wordsmith that uses their charm and intellect to feed your cheese habit. Real freedom, and from it comes real fun.

If it's there, you can interact with it. You can even do it in combat too...

Combat... oh yeah! There's so much to do that isn't fighting, that I almost forgot! The combat in D:OS, is quite simply, the best turn-based combat system ever devised. I'm not even going to describe it. Words don't do it justice.

The worst thing you can do, is ignore this game. It may 'look' like a generic RPG from screenshots, but once you're in, you're not getting out without loving it.

One thing I wish could be implemented is controller support. Then, this game would be absolute perfection.

10/10 Must buy.

reviewText:
Wow, this game is awesome. It harkens back to the days of Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura and Fallouts 1&2.

This game is gorgeous at times. The UI is very intuitive, and all of the game's systems are easy to figure out without consulting guides or manuals (at least for someone familiar with this type of game.)

The drop-in co-op is implemented very well. The only gripe I have is your partner doesn't create their own characters to use in your game; they play the ones you assign them that you've created. Not a big deal at all.

Also, I've run into a few bugs in the game, but nothing that has impeded my progress.

I heartily recommend this game for any old school turn-based RPG fans... or just RPG fans who want to play a great game.

reviewText:
I'm 26 years old. I've played RPG games all my life. I grew up playing games like Zelda, Diablo and Balder's Gate .etc. So, I feel pretty qualified to talk about RPG games :D

Divinity: Original Sin is potentially one of the best RPG games of this generation. It is definately a 'classic', and I would say that it's (basically) the modern day equivelent of Balder's Gate.

Let me put it plainly; if you like old-school role playing games like Diablo 1, Dungeons & Dragons, or Balder's Gate, then you *WILL* enjoy this game. No doubt. You will enjoy it even more if you have someone to play with too (the game supports two players, and you can either play on LAN, specific people over the internet, or in 'public games' on the internet where anyone can join) -- it really has something for everyone! (although i prefer to play solo, cos i'm an insocialable basturd xD)

But yea, I don't usually buy games unless they're like -80% sale, but this one was definitely worth it. I've spent about 120 hours so far on this game, and I'm only like 10% through the game (I keep deleting and remaking my characters cos I'm very indecisive on what setup to play xD), so that's value for money!!

I fully expect to spend over 1000 hours playing this game, since there is just so much content to explore and find... people to talk to, secrets to reveal... gawd I love this game :'D

Seriously. Buy this game. Now. o__o

reviewText:
Review @ 100 hours and level 18.

<tl;dr>
Despite having a few flaws this game is one of the most engaging for a long time, and worth the full asking price - don't wait for a sale, get it now!
</tl;dr>

My wife and I play this in LAN co-op mode, we bought this pre-release as we are fans of the genre but did not start playing until a few weeks after release to avoid the inevitable patch-aggrevation.

To gauge whether you have a similar taste to us, we loved:
- Baldur's Gate
- Neverwinter Nights
- Ultima series
- Sacred 1 & 2
- Diablo 1 & 2
- Titan Quest
- Eye of the Beholder
- old-school Sierra Online & Lucasarts games

After 200 collective hours of playing, we have not had a single crash (platform is Windows 8.1 x64) - this is noteworthy for modern games I think.

The things we like most about the game:
- the humour (at times subtle and possibly for older players, however)
- the camera style (not first-person or over-the-shoulder)
- the quests are not spoon-fed
- you are free to develop your characters as you want (no forced classes)
- ALT-tabbing works flawlessly and quickly

Things which have frustrated us at times, but not enough to dissuade from recommending the game:
- mis-clicking during combat due to animation of a mob
- the inventory UI does not feel polished (e.g. after dragging an item out of a container, clicking anywhere will be interpreted as a location for the character to move to)

For the NPC dialogues we can look at whichever screen we need to, but I can imagine the passive player in a co-op game might feel a little lost or left out if not in the same room as the active player.

We have had 1 quest which required a manual hack of a savegame to complete due to it disappearing entirely after selecting we'll talk about this later" - luckily a quick Google showed us what to hex-edit trivially to reset the quest/NPC status.

We have had no issues with performance
date: but our systems are not low-spec and not overclocked or bogged down with background processes - certainly no loading screens measured in minutes.\n\nIt is good to know that the game uses 1 core 100% all the time
recommended: so having at least a quad core CPU is advisable
hoursPlayed: as well as plenty of RAM
voteText: a 64-bit OS
helpfulPercent: good cooling and no overclocking."

reviewText:
Ok... This is a bold statement... and shouldn't be taken lightly. Divinity: Original Sin is the BEST RPG I've ever played. Nothing can touch it. It's also my GOTY, hands down.

Rarely does a developer put so much of their love and affection into a game. Larian have, and by doing so, they've changed the game, maybe even the rulebook for every RPG that follows. This is the new benchmark, probably for any genre.

Even if you don't like RPGs, D:OS will have something for you. Even if you're a casual gamer, it's so well paced, you could hop in for just half an hour at a time. But you wont.

You'll be drawn into a beautiful, complex and vibrant world of adventure, mystery and more importantly FUN.

D:OS won't hold your hand, or assume you're stupid. You can do ANYTHING from the get go. GO anywhere.

This freedom isn't just limited to what you can do, it's how you do it.

You're offered choices constantly, be it through clever dialogues with NPC's or gameplay itself. The game will know what you've done, who knows about it, and who it will effect and adjust itself accordingly.

I'm not going to offer any spoilers here past the first hour. That would be morally bankrupt. The beauty of this game, is discovering it for yourself.

D:OS doesn't stop you from doing what you want. You can treat people how you want, do quests any way you want and shape the story any way you want. This is role playing at it's finest. Actually *Playing a Role*. Want to be the bad guy with a penchant for stealing fine art from inns? Go ahead, or maybe you want to be the wordsmith that uses their charm and intellect to feed your cheese habit. Real freedom, and from it comes real fun.

If it's there, you can interact with it. You can even do it in combat too...

Combat... oh yeah! There's so much to do that isn't fighting, that I almost forgot! The combat in D:OS, is quite simply, the best turn-based combat system ever devised. I'm not even going to describe it. Words don't do it justice.

The worst thing you can do, is ignore this game. It may 'look' like a generic RPG from screenshots, but once you're in, you're not getting out without loving it.

One thing I wish could be implemented is controller support. Then, this game would be absolute perfection.

10/10 Must buy.

reviewText: My relationship with this game brings me back to Dragon Age: Origins. I'm not an old school PC RPG player, so I don't have any stories about Baldur's Gate or Planescape. Regardless, this is probably the best RPG to be released since Origins and has captured more of my time than I can scarcely begin to understand. The gameplay lends itself to thought and thankfully doesn't hold your hand with quest markers, flickering trails to the next objective or obvious build decisions. If you're not a veteran of the genre the game is going to sock you in the face over and over again, but it feels so good when you do finally learn to dodge the punch. Encounters, especially with bosses, seem unfair at the outset when they pit your 2 to 4 man group up against 5, 6 or 7+ enemies. A little element mixing and ingenuity can see two turns tilt a battle in your favor or bad positioning have you reloading in a heartbeat. You can use mages to deal massive AOE damage by combining elements such as fire and poison for huge explosions or catering to a melee character with massive magic buffs to create a massive wrecking ball. There's a certain level of sarcasm and wit peppered into the dialogue along with pop culture references that can bring a smile to the face without really overwhelming. Good music, nice looking areas--it's definitely worthy of all of the great reviews it's been getting. In a few weeks I'll probably have a 100+ hours into this and I'll still be coming back for more. There's even frickin' multiplayer, with rock-paper-scissor arguements that can come up between players on how to handle quest decisions. If you don't have a friend you can set your AI partner's behavior and experience two main characters disagreeing. It's fantastic. Oh, you can rob entire towns blind, too.

reviewText:
So many of the younger persons have been so spoiled growing up playing nothing but Diablo-like click fests, that they have no patience for a well thought out and deeper RPG experience.

Divinity: Original Sin, is throwback to the golden era of the cRPG. The age before Diablo's success spawned a new type of RPG with the most important element removed or given a back seat - THE STORY! Not to mention a watered down version of RPG combat - the button mash.

This game is nostalgic. It leaves me with a good feeling just thinking about returning to the game, and experiencing it with the attention and thought that it was designed for. There is great attention to detail, the writing is excellent and humor a fun diversion, and the combat forces you to think instead of like pointing at a group of monsters and clicking them to death.

This is what a real RPG game is all about! The developers did an excellent job with this.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this?  HELL YES!
This game is a mix of all the old school greats, Ultimas, Baldurs Gates, Torment, Fallout, etc.

What I liked alot:
Story - There is a huge fleshed out world, lots of lore, books, etc for those that choose to read everything. The actual main story was fleshed out and interesting, it made me want to finish the game to figure out what happened.

World - The world was pretty cool, very detailed with little things hiding everywhere for you to find.  They rewarded people that where willing to go adventuring.

Graphics - Graphics where great, I had everything maxed out and did't have any preformance issues or find a problem with anything.  There where several different tilesets as well, so the world didn't get boring for me on my run through the game.

Spell System - The spells where great.  Nice visual effects, can be mixed and matched to create extra nice effects, ie Lightning + Water.  This aspect also made you more careful, because if your own guy was in the water.... you get the meaning :). You had to be somewhat intelligent about what you cast also, spell effects would cause things like line of site issues, etc.  Hard to heal people when you drop a fireball between you and them and the place goes up in smoke and fire!

Comabt - I've read reviews about people complaining about the combat, but it's perfect for this game.  It's turned based, initiative style, there's numerous different ways to finish off encounters and fights. It was as good of a system as I could have asked for for a multi character party game while still maintaining control of each charcter with precision.



What I liked but I thought could use some more work:

Character Progression/Building- This was a little confusing at first, I didn't know what did what, what was good, etc. I had to do a little research outside of the game, but once I god how it worked, understood what was important and not so much I was good to go.  It was pretty easy to build an uber party, basically my 2 casters would buff my 2 frontline guys and they would go and destroy everything. With that being said maybe the difficulty could have been a little harder?

Questing - Questing was great, there was some awesome quests, things that made me laugh, etc.  Some of the quests where hard to figure out and I had to get help from outside resource sites with where to go next because there wasn't enough clues (for me anyhow) telling me where to go.  I'm not asking for a big arrow pointing to everything, but some  more direction would have been more helpful, either on the map or in the quest log.

Puzzles - Some of these where downright hard/impossible. I found myself looking for help more then a few times with how to solve puzzles, especiallly the weight puzzle. I have no idea how anyone would ever figure that out (This is after I tried for over an hour). Just asking for some more direction.

Crafting - The crafting was awesome and vastly helped out once I figured out how to use it but some of the blacksmithing stuff vs crafting stuff didn't make sense.  Regardless, make one of your characters have level 5 Crafting and Blacksmithing by the end of the game if you can.  There's numerous resource sites for how to make stuff also as the in-game books can be confusing, and are not organized, etc.


All in all, this is a great game.  The 9/10 reviews are spot on and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is nostalgic for an old school RPG in todays clothing.  The developers did an amazing job, and hopefully they have an expansion out soon, I know I'll be buying it.

reviewText:
A lot of people keep comparing this to Baldur's Gate, but it's more than that.  It has much of what was great about Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Icewind Dale, and Arcanum: of Steamworks and Magic Obscura... but with a lot of the gameplay and graphical advances you'd expect after 10+ years of time for the industry to advance.  There isn't much that's quite as satisfying as having two magic users using the environment and each others magic effects to boost damage...except maybe doing it with a friend via multiplayer.

So far my main gripe is the sound.  The music can drone on and make you want to mute it, and god help you if you want to read anything while standing next to a group of NPCs whose dialogue will loop with only a few seconds of blessed silence between.

The end result so far is a really good game.  I definitely recommend it, especially since you can always turn off sound.

reviewText:
A very solid game overall - a must-buy if you're a fan of old-school cRPGs.

The turn-based combat system is extremely deep and (especially in co-op mode) seems to help in making the combat not feel like a chore. It does have issues: often times it'll be hard to see where the edges of ground effects (fire, poison, etc.) are, especially if they're covered by grass. This has resulted in my characters taking unnecessary damage more times than I can count. Often times your character's vision will also be blocked for no reason, which can be frustrating. However, these issues are only minor and I expect they will be patched out in the near future.

The story is engaging and the quests are mostly interesting, but unfortunately (or fortunately if you're like me) there's barely any voice acting. That is forgivable, though, as the game has a gigantic amount of dialogue. If you like reading, just buy the game already!

One additional point I must bring up is the fact that the game starts off in a slow-ish manner. My friend and I were not very impressed by the combat system at the very beginning of the game, but it gets SO MUCH better after a few hours once you start getting more and more abilities to play around with.

To summarize: the game is very good, but not perfect. 100% recommended if you're into cRPGs, otherwise you might want to read around a bit more to make sure that the game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An intstant classic and a game made several years too late (where were you my whole life!?) Well, now it's finally going to release and I must say it's a very well made Ultima/Baulder's Gate styled game that will leave you doing random stuff for hours. Literally hours. I think that's the only bad quality of the game. You can play for eight hours straight and seemingly get nowhere. That was the charm of Ultima too, but in this case, for my life and where it is, I don't have the patience.

The graphics are very good for the isometric portrayal of the game world, and the interactions with the environment are a welcome sight to see. Although the world feels alive, the people feel dull. Many of the villagers will not help you much with quests as they all say the same thing and do little in hinting you where to go next. That just adds to the hours spent meandering around doing nothing. While I love it when a game does not hold your hand it must try better at making you understand the world you are playing in. Otherwise I'd love to see more map markers for quests.

Combat is highly rewarding. Finally we have a game where your tactical decisions mean a lot. I was expecting this from games like Dragon Age but that game never had the envronment as a tactic as much as this game does. Your characters matter, and a team of warriors will be ill prepared against magic while a team of rogues will die fast against a strong opponent. By using your partners to full effectiveness, it feels everyone has a place in the world.

The loot and trading is awesome and makes the game feel very free and open. You can do anything you want. Lastly, the music and menu design is very well done. All things considered this is a really well built game, with deep lore to explore, allows you to do anything you want, and keeps you progressing as you play. But I will warn you: be prepared to sink a few hundred hours on your first playthrough (unaided) since a few quests can be a bit overmuch to explore.

I'll also add, the first quests make it very slow to have multiple playthroughs of the game. If I were you I'd skip most of them just to get your playthroughs underway. Most of the stuff in the first town is talking and meandering and highly forgettable.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo I went against my own rule and bought an Alpha Early Access game on Steam. Divinity: Original Sin. Ive had my eye on it for a long time, and they released a collectors edition that comes with 2 copies of the game and both its predecessors, plus free launch DLC. So I caved. After playing the game, I definitely see why its still in early access and why save games wont be carrying over to final release but holy hell is it fun. Its a very diablo-esque dungeon crawler but the combat is turn based, rather than real time and a lot of the different skills play off eachother. For example, I can cast a rain storm over the battlefield which puts out any fires and eliminates the burning status effect. Then my wife casts a chain lightning and it does increased damage to every enemy it hits because theyre in the rain. The combinations are all over the place: oil+fire, water+lightning, theres a bunch. I definitely recommend at least looking into it, if this piques your interest.

reviewText:
Updated Review --
I like it!

To start with, the world is big, there's lot to do and see and, in some ways a bit too much - your quest log is going to get overwhelmingly full and you'll probably end up somewhere new wondering why the hell you're standing there and trying to remember what your original goal was five hours ago.

It looks beautiful, almost too much as it can be very easy to overlook something visually and start wondering what's gone wrong. In particular the ALT key to show items on the ground doesn't show all items, just 'equipable' stuff it seems. Unfortunantly there doesn't seem to be a way to have those items always show either, so you'll be holding down alt a lot.

The UI has seen quite a bit of improvement though there are still some bugs to work out, multiplayer even more so. Some examples are the combat log not scrolling, the dialogue not showing you what the other person selected in the log, and the combative dialoge forcing you to scroll up to see some of what was said. Those and a few other things could stand to be tweaked.

Progression is a little different from many modern games - you wont get a bunch of points every level that make a little difference but just one every few levels that will make a big difference. This also means not screwing up what you choose is important as, so far, I haven't come across a way to respec. Which is a shame since you're probably going to regret a point or two.

Combat is good but sloppy, you can pretty much count on setting things on fire you didn't mean to and having a spell hit a wall when it shows a hit. There's also something a little wacky about a few of the element interactions (fire not always exploding a poison cloud or fire healing a water enemy because it melted ice into a puddle are a couple of examples) - they may seem that way because it's all based on rolls but without the log showing all those odds it's a little hard to say for sure.
Despite all that, causing a massive chain-reaction of explosions or stunning a whole group of people standing in water is a lot of fun and working all your party members strengths together to take down someone 5 levels higher than you is great. Even stubmling into a devistating ambush and being wiped out is amusing and reminds you to save often.

The music included is fantastic too, though the provided soundtrack, if you got it, doesn't seem to include the full library that was apparently put into the game. I do hope even more music gets added at some point as well since their composer's illness cut into what had been prepared for the game.

It's a great game and once the last of the bugs are squished, and Larian does tend to be very good about patching, this game will be amazing.



Original Early Access Review --
So far, so good!

After the Dragon Knight games I was excited to hear something new was in the works. While it's not the same style of RPG, it's got a Baulder's Gate vibe that was still appealing enough to back it on Kickstarter. Indeed, as the crowd-funding went on and more details and goals were reached, it very much became a source of excitement for me.

After playing though some of the Alpha I was encouraged. The UI had some rough spots, there were some very obvious bugs and some subtle ones but even the update to Beta included a vast array of improvments that left a much more polished feel.

Obviously things are still going to change and I've held back from playing too much before the final version, but from what I've seen so far, if you enjoy a big RPG with what seems to be a delightful level of depth and want turn-based combat where stratedgy plays a real factor, it's certainly worth checking out.

reviewText:
NeutralPretty slow moving at the start of the game
The game requires a reasonable amount of patience
Not a lot of direction in where to go / what to do
Character and gameplay progression feels very unconventional. You have to take initiative to make sure you character is getting new skills and increasing in power
PositivesFeels like a proper RPG
Heaps of freedom of choice
Interesting and varied character creation

Rewards exploration
Art direction is solid, lots of interesting environments and maintains a consistent level of quality even with its unconventionally saturated colour palette

NegativesThere are times when you will probably need a walkthrough to progress because it is not clear how to progress otherwise

reviewText:
Recently I replayed Baldur's Gate and I was horrified on how terrible it had aged and how clunky it was to play. But it also reminded me that that kind of classic RPG barely exists anymore. The only game in the last few years I can think of that went into the same direction (gameplay wise, not thematically ofc) was Shadowrun Returns, and with limited success.

Well look no further, because Divinity is that modern day Baldur's Gate experience we didn't get in many years. It's beautiful, complex, thoughtful and challenging. The battles are turn-based with action points. Every class and magic school has it's own niche and reason to exist. It's also very challenging early on and you'll have to make use of every tool at your disposal to get through. Unlike past games in the genre it's not so hard that you'll constantly feel forced to save scum however. For me it was a perfect balance. Character customization is complex enough to motivate, though I would have liked to see more talents. Lot's of loot too, though I had terrible luck or the system needs some work, by the end I was still running around partially with Lv 8 equipment because nothing better ever dropped.

There is also crafting which is probably a bit overpowered and clunky to use. The crafting is also responsible for a very cluttered inventory system. But we've seen worse back in the day (arrow management in BG...).

The only real negative I have for the game is that I could have lived without the find the 5 clickable pixels" hidden object-style exploration puzzles the game sometimes throws at you. But everything else gets a big thumps-up."

reviewText: This game is honestly... I... well, I can't really put it into words. Many people compare this to old-school RPGs like Neverwinter Nights, Baldur's Gate, and Ultima, and while I can honestly say I see the homage quite clearly, D:OS introduces many new concepts too. Co-op works seamlessly and flawlessly, the editor is great, and I can't wait to see what modders do with this game. My only main complaint about the game is the inventory system - it's a little clunky and hard to navigate at times, especially when you have a lot of items. The writing is clever and humorous, and I just found myself reading books and immersing myself in the world for hours on end - and I continue to do so as I play through the game.\n\nSo, how do you know if this game is for you? Honestly, if you've enjoyed any old-school isometric RPGs in the past (or currently), chances are that you'll enjoy this game. For a newcomer to the genre of CRPGs? Watch a couple videos, if you have friends who personally like the game, shoot them a message and ask them why it's great. I also realize it's a pretty hefty price tag, but I honestly think it's worth it - especially with all that comes shipped with the game.

reviewText:
This. This is great. No predetermined classes, customise all your characters to your hearts delight. Quests do not handhold you by placing quest markers, you have to really read the dialogue and pay attention to everything. Morality is subjective and not just an obvious choice between black and white (mostly). And exploration. Exploration is everything in this game and if you do not explore, you will miss a hell of a lot of stuff.

Combat is your 'traditional' action point based system (i.e. no modern game really uses it) and its compentent enough. But the effects are amazing. Elements will react with each other; fire and water turns to burning hot steam, explosive gas can get ignited etc. Feel the satisfaction of electrifying ten people who 'happen' to stand in water. :p

Admittedly this game isn't for people who like, maybe, the more streamlined combat and quests of Skyrim, where all the combat is real time and the quests mostly point you towards the next dungeon filled with loot and monsters. But then, this is supposed to be THE modern RPG that brings back all the stuff that we 'lost' in the time of Baldur's Gate.

So. 9.5/10. I'll never give 10/10 because a 10/10 game will never exist. But consider this game close to it.

reviewText: First, to the developers, a heartfelt thank you. Probably my first computer gaming experience was Ultima VII. I never finished it. It was too long, I was too young, and it was too hard to get games to run in the first place back then (memory managers? who remembers that crap?). It has, in the rouchly 25 years of gaming since then, been my white whale. I think about it constantly and long to play it again and finally finish it.\n\nDivinity: Original Sin captures so much of what made that game great to me, and so much of what simply doesn't exist in gaming today. It shines creatively, both in a refreshing take on stats/classes/skills/etc, as well as the story. I personally found the graphics to be very good as well. Art is a purely subjective thing to discuss, and I won't say that this game is for everyone. But I will say, if you want a deep role playing experience, turn-based combat, and a pool of nostalgia deep enough to drown in, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
The last time I felt this gleeful about the sheer freedom and breadth of possibilities of a game was playing Deus Ex for the first time. Divinity: Original Sin is maximalist game design philosophy at its absolute best in RPG form, even if the individual parts arent all top tier. I hadnt played a proper party based CRPG since KOTOR and NWN back in the day and wasnt particularly interested in the latest wave of Kickstarter revivals either, but curiosity and its promise of clever turn based tactics got the best of me after noticing D:OS had been the number one seller on Steam for WEEKS after its launch. I checked out a random gameplay vid on Youtube, which ended up being a whole encounter early on, which was enough by itself to immediately sell me on the game. Lets be perfectly honest here, the battle system is the star here and is by far my favorite RPG combat ever. Seriously, nothing but the most complex SRPGs can even hold a candle to the veritable chemistry set of options available to players here. The encounters, at least in the first act, make excellent use of these systems resulting in around 30 hours of stiffly challenging tactical bliss. Just a few fight highlights just in the first map of the game:

After realizing that fire ignites poison surfaces and hard landings cause impact damage, I teleport dropped my fire elemental summon close to enemies in a poison pool causing the entire pool to explode, in addition to the impact damage, killing everything in it instantly.
Getting ambushed and surrounded on all sides by about 20 exploding barrel skeletons and having to cleverly manipulate chain reactions while not instakilling my party of 4 in the process.
The final boss of Act 1 being some massive demon er flanked by the three other, also quite difficult, sub-bosses of the act. Took me a few tries but I eventually took him down with no casualties after 30+ minutes of grueling combat. My favorite boss fight in a turn based game by a mile.
Outside of combat, its still pretty damn good except for the overall plot and main story writing. I took a liking to the goofy tone (especially the talking animals, like my boy Unsinkable Sam and the murder victims dog, who surprising came into combat to help me fight some recently exhumed corpses), which some regard as out of place in a game like this but to me it makes perfect sense. When your various methods of interactivity are so playful and exuberant, why contradict yourself with the standard dreary dark fantasy self-seriousness? Speaking of playful interactions, theres plenty of it outside of fighting. Pretty much everything in the world exists as a manipulable object with its own physics properties, health and such Quests can be solved in a crazy amount of ways, which is necessary given the journal doesnt give you exact information about the what and where. Investigations actually feel like investigations, not errands as they often do in quest marker oriented games. Anything that reminds me of Morrowind in that regard is a plus in my book.

The difficulty and quality of the encounters take a dive after the Act 1, and to be quite honest I didnt even finish it. Act 1 is transcendent enough to where that barely matters to me, and could be my GOTY based on it alone. What keeps me excited is the continued attempts of director Swen Vincke and Larian Studios to understand where they went wrong and to make iterations on this engine and formula for D:OS and future games[www.lar.net], building up towards what they call the very big RPG that will dwarf them all. Theyve immediately shot up into my pantheon of favorite developers along with FROM, Platinum, and EAD Tokyo and their future looks bright as hell.

Shoutouts to the Kickstarter backers and and their collective milli and early access players for helping to make this happen with the balance and volume of stuff it deserved.

reviewText:
This was my first PC RPG, so my review is without any nostalgia for this type of gameplay. And I loved the game. It wasn't perfect -- at times some things enfuriated me (backstabbing related usually), but overall it was amazing. I was obsessed. I still am.

The good:
1. The battle system is great. There's a lot to think about and reason to pay careful attention to what enemies are doing on their turn. The game can be very hard, so optimizing your moves and performing smart combinations matter.  Magic spells can interact with each other in really rad ways.
2. There are a lot of ways to complete quests, but it is still challenging to complete them.
3. Non-combat skills feel very important! Crafting, being able to talk to animals, teleportation -- all of these and more can help a lot.  With a high enough pickpocket talent you can steal from anybody in the game (who has items to trade, such as all shop keepers).
4. SO MUCH TO DO in every town! It really encourages exploration and does a good job of rewarding you.
5. Side stories and quests can be very interesting and funny.
6. The coop is well implemented. There are fun dialogs you can argue with your partner in. And it makes exploring towns go much faster when you split up.

The bad:
1. I've heard people say the UI for this game is good. It's not. This must be a compared to other PC RPGS" thing.  Your inventory will be a mess without enough good options for organization. Crafting can be a real pain because of this. Dragging an item through your inventory page by page is annoying. You can look at "only ingredients" in your inventory
date: but this doesn't help when you need to combine an ingredient with a weapon. I got around this by dragging things into pouches for crafting.\n2. The learning curve is a bit rough
recommended: especially with certain classes. I hated my Rogue for his first 6 levels or so. Part of the problem is that there isn't a very good UI for backstabbing.  Enemies stand in all sorts of weird poses

Especially in the first town. It's best to just explore each town fully then leave the town only when you find you must (especially the first town

reviewText:
A very solid game overall - a must-buy if you're a fan of old-school cRPGs.

The turn-based combat system is extremely deep and (especially in co-op mode) seems to help in making the combat not feel like a chore. It does have issues: often times it'll be hard to see where the edges of ground effects (fire, poison, etc.) are, especially if they're covered by grass. This has resulted in my characters taking unnecessary damage more times than I can count. Often times your character's vision will also be blocked for no reason, which can be frustrating. However, these issues are only minor and I expect they will be patched out in the near future.

The story is engaging and the quests are mostly interesting, but unfortunately (or fortunately if you're like me) there's barely any voice acting. That is forgivable, though, as the game has a gigantic amount of dialogue. If you like reading, just buy the game already!

One additional point I must bring up is the fact that the game starts off in a slow-ish manner. My friend and I were not very impressed by the combat system at the very beginning of the game, but it gets SO MUCH better after a few hours once you start getting more and more abilities to play around with.

To summarize: the game is very good, but not perfect. 100% recommended if you're into cRPGs, otherwise you might want to read around a bit more to make sure that the game is for you.

reviewText: There are a lot of reviews, and perhaps one more isn't needed. But hopefully this will be a good one for those of you on the fence, since this game is not usually on sale. In summary, yes, this game is worth $39.99. No question!\n\nFirst, the positives. For a game funded through Kickstarter and seemingly made under financial duress, the polish is that of a larger publisher's work. There are some aspects of it that do scream needed more budget
date:
but overall, this is a fine piece of work.

The gameplay itself is also fun, yet simple. Combat relies a lot on terrain, use of elements, distance, position... for such a seemingly simple setup, the combat can get really creative. You can sneak around and plant oil barrels in preparation for a fight with an invisible character, and then set off a giant explosion with fire. Of course, then fiery oil is everywhere and no one can see anything, and if you use a lot of barrels, you might get caught in the spreading flames. Combat in Divinity is often like this, with crazy sequences.

The story is also not just a placeholder. It's funny, self-aware, sometimes terrifying. The game doesn't take itself too seriously but it can get very dark. The campy, dark humor is very refreshing, and conversations with NCPs more entertaining than it should be.

The character creation is very flexible, and at a later point in the game you can even reset your character (!), at the cost of re-quiring all your skillbooks. I haven't got to play CO-OP, but I imagine the reset was for this kind of gameplay.

There are some negatives, not insignificant. The graphics can be extremely frustrating to target in combat, as the area to click on for enemies actually moves around with the opponent's outline. The UI, especially how items and the stash works, is absolutely cluttered and terrible. The bags you get don't make it any simpler. The other problem is the game likes to use puzzles, and these puzzles are often absolutely opaque. There's no way to figure them out, or the solution is so narrow and specific, you probably would have never thought of it.

The paper-rock-scissors event to solve disputes between characters is utterly irritating, especially in single play. I imagine in COOP it's probably hilarious. But I don't like that it occurs with NPCs, since it's really just a random chance to overcome your opponent.

These cons aside, Divinity is a really magical game. It's pretty, it's fun, you can play with a friend (which I will do very soon!) and you won't regret purchasing it, even at full price. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is this year's most positive surprise, without doubt. It's very much an old school RPG, with a large world that doesn't scale to your level, and plenty of complex game mechanics and character customization, in the best RPG fashion. The main plot could've been something more interesting, but then again it's constructed in a way to leave lot of room for personal choice of style, trying its best to avoid black and white morals.

One of the most interesting aspect of the game is the two main characters, and their possibility to interact and contradict each other. The games uses a rock-paper-scissor social game mechanic to resolve social disputes, which I think earns major extra points: It's a simple mechanic that works really well; much better than a simplistic skill check like in most RPGs.

I personally find the game's crafting mechanics a little bit confusing, but I guess they're built in a way to promote experimentation and trial and error, you'll find crafting instructions within ingame books, but otherwise there's no information on it. Barely anything in manual.

The best part of the game is the turn-based combat. Really. It fits this genre perfectly. Combat can be very challenging at times, and the game mechanics really take advantage of the turn-based with lots of complexity e.g. regarding the relation of the different magical elements, which affect each other in multitudes of ways creating emergent complexity that leaves a lot of room for creativity. Combat is very much a thinking man's game in Divinity: Original Sin. Large number of combatants can make the fights a bit frustrating at times, but then again, you can save any time, any where, even during combat rounds, so although the fights can be a challenge, you're welcome to save scum your way to victory.

Overall, it's an excellent RPG with old school feel (lots of text to read!), pleasant overall graphics and very solid game mechanics. It's definitely worth the monies if you like old school RPGs and don't mind reading through a lot of text (the dialogue can be a bit bloated at times).

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is wonderful.  From the serious characters to the quirky characters to the crafting and the combat, this game delivers on all counts.  Improving it would be difficult, though not entirely impossible.

Two things I love about it: 1. Every battle presents some degree of challenge with few exceptions as the adversaries are equally matched to the playable characters.  Even a difference of one level can be devastating (e.g. a level 7 adversary tends to annihilate a level 6 party member).  This does bar access to some regions of the world, but it does so organically.  You can attempt it and fail or you could mark it on your map and return later.

2. All of the skills (special attacks) gained remain useful throughout the game.  In many RPGs, the early skills become useless partway through and/or get replaced by upgraded versions.  In D:OS, they remain pertinent and never get replaced or outclassed by an upgraded version.  This is due to the skills scaling in effect as the characters progress improving their attributes and equipping superior weapons as well as to the old school combat system.  For instance, Minor Heal remains useful later on because its cooldown decreases as Intelligence increases and so, my healer could cast it every single turn by level 13.  I use it while Strong Regenerate cools down and out of combat to quickly recover the party.

One thing of which to be aware: The game begins slowly and the beginning is not overly engaging.  It is a game that gets better as you play it which has pros and cons.  The pro is that it is wonderful as I said; the con, that many people give up on it early on.  Honestly, I did not play it for a while because it did not engage me as I am accustomed to games doing.  Give it a few hours and once you can leave Cyseal without being murdered by undead, you can really start enjoying it.

reviewText:
An epic RPG with a lot of player autonomy. Although there are some tutorials, this wonderful game takes a more classic approach and lets the player figure out most things on his own.

To summarize:
+ A great deal of content. I've played for about 100 hours and I haven't finished my first playthrough yet.
+ Much player autonomy. You'll feel free to explore and learn about the world at your own pace.
+ Investigating! You'll do a lot of detective work in your quests. You're a lot like an inquisitor, trying to find and destroy evil.
+ A good story, with quite a few twists and surprises.
+ Wonderful, turn-based combat.

- Not much character development. It's possible I may have been spoiled by modern RPGs, but I reacted badly to this.
- A small of amount of audible dialogue. Most interactions are done through text. Many players are ok with this though.
- Too much running sometimes. There is a fast travel system, but you'll often find that you have to run great distances, with nothing to do but wait until the characters reach the destination.

reviewText:
It is hard to pinpoint what exactly is so great about Divinity:Original Sin, but I think that is what makes it so good. Everything is just... right. Everything is the way it is supposed to be, without any added gimmicks. The dialogues are fun, the story is good, the environment is highly interactive, the inventory system & character management is superb, and the fresh take on turn-based combat is, I dare say; something that should from here on out be considered standard for games of this kind.

While writing this, I still have not tried the multiplayer function, but given that it runs smoothly and bug-free(like the singleplayer certainly has), I can't imagine it being anything less than a great way to spend a weekend.

If you like RPGs I highly recommend you get this.

reviewText:
If you have any doubts about gameplay and turn based combat, don't worry and get this game if you like RPG's.

Pros:
+ Innovative, engaging and entertaining combat system which you have to make a plan and have a decent strategy (I mean a real strategy, tanking with tanks and attacking from range with mages/archers is definitely not enough to win most of the battles.)
+ Diversive path/build options, you can build your charecters however you want and it would work.
+ Smooth gameplay, nice GUI (which could be little bit better) no bugs, no mess, no sloppyness. Everything has adjusted perfectly.
+ Pretty funny. NPC's, dialogues, quests etc. there are moment that will make you laugh out loud.
+ Nice graphics, wonderful music.
+ Game does not hold your hand, thus enables you to feel accomplishment.
Cons:
- Looting, and crafting( which is pretty diversive) felt a bit dull and unsatisfactory.
- The map is not that diversive and big in comparison with other RPG's.
- Optimization could be better. Plenty of people (including me) suffers from low-FPS problems.
- I hated Rock-Paper-Scissors which I happen lose more often than I win. So I hate it.

That's all. In short, game is really wonderful and worth every penny.  Now I will head back to the game...

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic, game of the year quite easily for me. Hell, I would say that this is easily the game of the new millenium so far, damn near nothing can even remotely come close to how much fun I have had with this game. It might damn near supplant Baldur's Gate 2 as my favorite game of all time.

Ok, I've gushed about it enough but I haven't said a damn thing about the game proper. The gameplay is fantastic, this game encourages exploration out the , there are secrets and easter eggs everywhere. Combat is satisfying and magic is powerful with many great area denial abilities. The story is cliche, but in a good way in my personal opinion. It really feels like a good old fashioned campaign of D&D with great friends (and that one  but you'll figure out which companion that guy is.) Dialogue and writing overall is quite good with plenty of humor and it never really takes itself seriously.

Character customization is pretty strong, at least in the vein of what your character can do, not appearance so much. DivOS follows a classless system that is flexible enough to allow for multiclassing to become every bit as powerful as specializing is, though the game does stumble in the area of having a few non-combat skills be mostly useless in many situations. Lockpicking for instance can be very useless, since every chest has a key which can be found via exploration or pickpocketing, or by simply bashing/blasting the chest itself open if you so desire. Now as to customising your characters appearance there are limited options, but at the very least it is possible to dye your armors a different color so that you can look a specific way, though it can be difficult to find enough dyes to get your clothes set.

When it comes to loot, DivOS went the randomly generated route. Randomly generated loot has some pros and cons, just like hand place loot does. The cons of randomly generated loot is that to many the loot never really feels special and will often be useless for people in the party and in DivOS that can certainly be the case at times. However I also submit that randomly generated loot encourages exploration every bit as much as hand placed loot does. People often cite Morrowind as an excellent example of the glories of hand placed loot, with many otherwise useless caves holding a valuable artifact that rewards you for exploring it. While certainly true, it is really only rewarding the first time around, since you will always know that that item is there so you always know to go there to get it. Morrowind veterans, myself included, know of dozens of place to get powerful artifacts with minimal effort, and while fun it can rapidly become a ritual for the game, which can swing either way of being great or terrible. DivOS on the otherhand opts for a more Diablo-esque loot system, with randomized loot that encourages you to seek chests and fight bosses for the best stuff which I find to be quite enjoyabe as well. Ultimately I enjoy both systems provided they are done well, I just felt it was something you need to know.

Graphics are perfectly passable and enjoyable, it is always simple to tell what everything is and the art style of the game is quite good with few standout ridiculous armors or weapons, barring most of the robes unfortunately. Sound design is as per usual for all Divinity games absolutely excelent, with an amazing soundtrack made up of  excellently remastered tracks from past divinity games as well as many new tracks. Voice acting, what little there is of it, is enjoyable...at least the first few times you hear it, but it will eventually drive you to hate it, or love it. Personally I have taken to loving some of the idle chatter of some NPCs, and hating others.

Game length is quite satisfying as well, sitting at around 60ish hours from what I understand. I personally took significantly longer since I wound up developing a taste for reloading boss fights to do them over and over again, but I can confidently say that of my 200 hours as of writing only 20 of them were spent on the game back when it was in early access, and I enjoyed all 200 of them a great deal, and look forward to adding more via coop and mods.

I can go on for a while longer, but for the sake of simply ending this review I'll just say that I can't recommend this game enough, Larian created a true classic with this one.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo I went against my own rule and bought an Alpha Early Access game on Steam. Divinity: Original Sin. Ive had my eye on it for a long time, and they released a collectors edition that comes with 2 copies of the game and both its predecessors, plus free launch DLC. So I caved. After playing the game, I definitely see why its still in early access and why save games wont be carrying over to final release but holy hell is it fun. Its a very diablo-esque dungeon crawler but the combat is turn based, rather than real time and a lot of the different skills play off eachother. For example, I can cast a rain storm over the battlefield which puts out any fires and eliminates the burning status effect. Then my wife casts a chain lightning and it does increased damage to every enemy it hits because theyre in the rain. The combinations are all over the place: oil+fire, water+lightning, theres a bunch. I definitely recommend at least looking into it, if this piques your interest.

Early Access Review

These guys KNOW how to do a Kickstarter campaign better than most any developer I've seen.  They constantly keep you in the loop about EVERYTHING they are doing and why and showing updated videos covering everything with superb answers to live questions.  It's been a thrill to watch this game come into being and it's the first one that has surpassed all my expectactions.  The Turn Based nature is so versatile, characters can be so unique, Co-Op is just way beyond what I would have expected and then even more beyond what I could have expected is the Editor that allows everyone to create their own games to freely share with others.  Not since Never Winter Nights have I see this attempted.  It's just amazing all they have been able to complete and I'm so happy to have been able to help Kick Start this wonderful achievement.   I'm still holding off to play more fully until the full release but from testing it all out regularly everything has been improved on steadily and I haven't come accross any  bugs personally.  It all looks beautiful and deep.  I've given to many Kickstarter Campaigns, but this one has really been the best by a long shot in covering all that a Kickstarter campaign should.  I hope many other developers go by their example.  While waiting I've just gotted into Divinity 2 which I somehow missed along the way and it's been a blast too!  Larian and CD Project are now my two favorite developers!  Oh and surely check out the Twitch TV interviews that go along with this game.  They are soo good.  One just uploaded on the 18th even.  But check out the ones before it if you have any questions because they go into great depth.

Do you long for the days of yore? The bygone era of endless rpg's that would immerse you and make you lose all track of time?
Games that would let you decide the way to play, the way to react and the actual outcome of the game's story? The days that games that would let you get through those long, cold and wet winters when no child (friend or foe) could be found roaming the neighborhood? No need to dream about the past any longer:

Divinity: Original Sin is an ode to those glory days, when RPG's could immerse and entice you so deeply that you would look up after 3 months of playing and ask yourself; How long have I been away from society? Do my friends still know my name? Are my parents still alive? And the most important question of all; Why haven't I finished this game yet?

GO BUY THIS  RIGHT NOW!

reviewText: First, to the developers, a heartfelt thank you. Probably my first computer gaming experience was Ultima VII. I never finished it. It was too long, I was too young, and it was too hard to get games to run in the first place back then (memory managers? who remembers that crap?). It has, in the rouchly 25 years of gaming since then, been my white whale. I think about it constantly and long to play it again and finally finish it.\n\nDivinity: Original Sin captures so much of what made that game great to me, and so much of what simply doesn't exist in gaming today. It shines creatively, both in a refreshing take on stats/classes/skills/etc, as well as the story. I personally found the graphics to be very good as well. Art is a purely subjective thing to discuss, and I won't say that this game is for everyone. But I will say, if you want a deep role playing experience, turn-based combat, and a pool of nostalgia deep enough to drown in, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
An epic RPG with a lot of player autonomy. Although there are some tutorials, this wonderful game takes a more classic approach and lets the player figure out most things on his own.

To summarize:
+ A great deal of content. I've played for about 100 hours and I haven't finished my first playthrough yet.
+ Much player autonomy. You'll feel free to explore and learn about the world at your own pace.
+ Investigating! You'll do a lot of detective work in your quests. You're a lot like an inquisitor, trying to find and destroy evil.
+ A good story, with quite a few twists and surprises.
+ Wonderful, turn-based combat.

- Not much character development. It's possible I may have been spoiled by modern RPGs, but I reacted badly to this.
- A small of amount of audible dialogue. Most interactions are done through text. Many players are ok with this though.
- Too much running sometimes. There is a fast travel system, but you'll often find that you have to run great distances, with nothing to do but wait until the characters reach the destination.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is this year's most positive surprise, without doubt. It's very much an old school RPG, with a large world that doesn't scale to your level, and plenty of complex game mechanics and character customization, in the best RPG fashion. The main plot could've been something more interesting, but then again it's constructed in a way to leave lot of room for personal choice of style, trying its best to avoid black and white morals.

One of the most interesting aspect of the game is the two main characters, and their possibility to interact and contradict each other. The games uses a rock-paper-scissor social game mechanic to resolve social disputes, which I think earns major extra points: It's a simple mechanic that works really well; much better than a simplistic skill check like in most RPGs.

I personally find the game's crafting mechanics a little bit confusing, but I guess they're built in a way to promote experimentation and trial and error, you'll find crafting instructions within ingame books, but otherwise there's no information on it. Barely anything in manual.

The best part of the game is the turn-based combat. Really. It fits this genre perfectly. Combat can be very challenging at times, and the game mechanics really take advantage of the turn-based with lots of complexity e.g. regarding the relation of the different magical elements, which affect each other in multitudes of ways creating emergent complexity that leaves a lot of room for creativity. Combat is very much a thinking man's game in Divinity: Original Sin. Large number of combatants can make the fights a bit frustrating at times, but then again, you can save any time, any where, even during combat rounds, so although the fights can be a challenge, you're welcome to save scum your way to victory.

Overall, it's an excellent RPG with old school feel (lots of text to read!), pleasant overall graphics and very solid game mechanics. It's definitely worth the monies if you like old school RPGs and don't mind reading through a lot of text (the dialogue can be a bit bloated at times).

reviewText:
Overall I have been very pleased with this game.  I played the original BG and NW series, Icewind Dale my favorite.  This game brings a lot of those rpg and turned-based 4-person squad elements with a fresh take on the open world / roaming environment that feels similar to playing the Ultima series for me. I'm not very far at the time of this post, maybe 15+ hours, and I've enjoyed every moment of it.

The graphics are easy on the eye at ultra settings on a modest machine.  It defaulted to those on a AMD FX 6300 / Radeon 6800. UI is pretty standard as the come.  The only thing is the, rather important, button on the right which is how you teleport.  Wish that one was more evident... sadly responsible for 30 mins of my play time.

The way you can split you party is very cool imo.  At one point one of my two main characters was about to die in combat on the next round (surrounded).  If both of your two main characters die you lose and load. (lots of f5/f8)  I fled with my other main character and one side character back to town and was able to regroup in real time while my other main character stayed in combat awiting their return.  I ran the other two back into the fight and was able to prevent his death.  While some may see this as a cheap way out or breaking game mechanics there is also the possibility that those returning character run into another mob and I would have two seperate battles to wage, or manage to merge them back into one.

Your characters have conversations with the party that you control. Doesn't really have a place in the SP mode (although it does change stats in some cases) and you can turn it off in the options but in MP mode it comes into play as if you don't agree with the person your playing with you can argue and try to intimiate/charm/reason with them.  And finally a draw will bring rock-paper-scissors to decide it all.  Another new element that I am indifferent on but for the record have yet to play multi.

Crafting is a nice addition.  You learn your recipes by book reading and from there it's a drag-and-drop process mostly.  However keeping all the ingredients can get messy in the inventory.

Soudtrack is quite enjoyable and the audio is well done.  VOs are ok, but honestly very few make it immersive.  The main story is not bad so far but I've been bouncing all over the place with side quests and have much more to do.

It's one of those what's over there?" games that makes you hate the next day at work from lack of sleep.  I would give it a 9 or 10.  I bought it at $40

reviewText:
Short and sweet:

I did not play the other Divinity titles, and I'm not one to play Dungeons and Dragons in real life, though I can understand the appeal. That being said Divinity: Original Sin (DOS) is hands down the best RPG I've played in recent years from a gameplay perspective. I'd recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the RPG genre, as it will not let you down. I've taken my first taste of a Divinity title and now all I want is more; with more multiplayer components and systems that support 4-player (or even 6-8 players) out of the box.

The turn-based gameplay is absolutely perfect; the classes (that you can completely customize yourself) are diverse and fun to play, leaving a lot of replay value in the game although the campaign itself is massive enough alone. Graphically the game looks great and after a quick graphic-streaming fix in the game files it ran seamlessly at 144FPS 2560x1440 resolution.

I'd heavily recommend a decent 4-player mod or 4-player edit as with 4 people the game is even more fun; though by itself it would still offer people a good experience. Even with the massive content rich evnironment myself and all those I know who love this game are left craving more; different campaigns from the communities and DLC from the developers bringing us new campaigns!

reviewText:
Graphics: 5/5
Soundtrack: 5/5
Gameplay: 5/5
Writing: 5/5
Tone: 5/5
Multiplayer Mechanics: 5/5
UI: 3/5
Bugs: a few, but they're not bad and are usually funny.

I want to say first that, like many gamers, I'm sick of fantasy games. It seems like developers believe RPG and Fantasy are interchangable genres.

I had this game in my inventory for several months. My best friend bought it for me, but my backlog of games was so long I didn't want to waste a few hours on yet another fantasy RPG. I was sure I would be disappointed and annoyed by the experience. To top it off, the game was early access, and I dislike early access games with a passion.
So, I didn't touch it. I ignored it. Which, honestly, was a mistake.

When I did pick it up, it was at my significant other's behest. We could play it together, so if I didn't like it, he would know why. I gave it a shot. I was pleasantly surprised. The graphics were lovely, but honestly, graphics stopped being important to me after Aion seduced me and stomped all over me. The sounds were nice, too, but I don't value sound in a game. What really sold me in the first hour I played was the gameplay.

Most of my experience in my 10 years of gaming has been with MMOs, which are the epitome of copy and paste combat. No matter if you fight a fire elemental or the king of skeletons, you have a rotation, and it doesn't really change fight to fight. Divinity: Original Sin blasts that concept out of the water. There is no rotation in Divinity: Original Sin. If you try to use the same tactics, fight to fight, you won't defeat enemies. Moreover, most of your attacks will create new environments for you to take advantage of. Finally, a game where you have an effect on your surroundings and the surroundings effect you. Before Divinity: Original Sin, I hated the concept of turn-based combat in video games; I thought it slowed the pacing down in a way that broke immersion. In Divinity, it's completely necessary and appropriate. You will need a turn-based system and a slower pacing in order to plan and adjust to the constantly changing combat situation. This is a system of gameplay that rewards thought and creativity.

While the amazing gameplay was what hooked me, what got me to stay was the writing. It's not Shakespeare, but goodness it's fun and light and enjoyable. I'm not going to experience a life changing experience from revelations inspired by this game, but I do laugh and care what will happen next, and that's a whole lot more than I can say for most games. I have to admit, I skip dialogue in Skyrim and most other games because I don't really tend to care about the details. I read every little word in Divinity, even if it's a dumb skill book, because it's fun and funny and interesting.

And, well, the most important thing to me in most games are multiplayer interactions. Is it worthwhile to have a friend along? Is interacting with said friend beneficial to gameplay? Am I going to still like my friend after playing this game with them? The answers respectfully are yes, yes, and yes. Even typically arduous and painful aspects of dual player games have been streamlined to be barely noticable. Is your buddy too far away from you? Teleport to them. Do you need to trade something to your buddy but they're across the map? Just right click the item to send it to them. Are you mad at your buddy? Hit them with lightning. It's like the developers played multiplayer games before and learned the common pitfalls of playing them, then decided to get rid of the annoyances.

My biggest gripe with the game is honestly tiny. The reason I rated the UI 3/5 isn't because of the skill bar or the minimap. I'm simply annoyed that the camera angles are fixed to a small range of positions. It makes it hard to loot some items or spot some details. Most of the time, you can work around it by hitting ALT, but it's hard to interact with some things if they're close to a positionally challenged wall nevertheless.

Yeah, it's worth the money. Buy and and buy it for a buddy, too.
