While the amazing gameplay was what hooked me, what got me to stay was the writing. It's not Shakespeare, but goodness it's fun and light and enjoyable. I'm not going to experience a life changing experience from revelations inspired by this game, but I do laugh and care what will happen next, and that's a whole lot more than I can say for most games. I have to admit, I skip dialogue in Skyrim and most other games because I don't really tend to care about the details. I read every little word in Divinity, even if it's a dumb skill book, because it's fun and funny and interesting.

And, well, the most important thing to me in most games are multiplayer interactions. Is it worthwhile to have a friend along? Is interacting with said friend beneficial to gameplay? Am I going to still like my friend after playing this game with them? The answers respectfully are yes, yes, and yes. Even typically arduous and painful aspects of dual player games have been streamlined to be barely noticable. Is your buddy too far away from you? Teleport to them. Do you need to trade something to your buddy but they're across the map? Just right click the item to send it to them. Are you mad at your buddy? Hit them with lightning. It's like the developers played multiplayer games before and learned the common pitfalls of playing them, then decided to get rid of the annoyances.

My biggest gripe with the game is honestly tiny. The reason I rated the UI 3/5 isn't because of the skill bar or the minimap. I'm simply annoyed that the camera angles are fixed to a small range of positions. It makes it hard to loot some items or spot some details. Most of the time, you can work around it by hitting ALT, but it's hard to interact with some things if they're close to a positionally challenged wall nevertheless.

Yeah, it's worth the money. Buy and and buy it for a buddy, too.

reviewText:
Almost all of my hours in this game were spent in the first zone, because I played the game as soon as it showed up with a freind of mine. I enjoyed it a lot, but after a while it began to wear on me. I did the same stuff over, and over, and over again and while I had fun for the most part, it began to bore me with how, sometimes, the game had so few choices.

sometimes there's two or three ways to complete things with minimal differences, which don;t make much of an impact on the story. Sometimes they do, sometimes they don't. You can send a bunch of imps to get killed by a demon and your freind imp just gets a little mad and carries on like nothing happened. Or, you can lose a game of ING ROCK PAPER SCISSORS and have an entire town turn on you.

There have been at least ten different occasions where I, having the upper hand in the persuasion arguement, lose despite having DOUBLE the stat of the other person, and then have an entire town attack me. Now, you might say, that if i was to save then that wouldn't be a problem - and sure, but most of the time I didn't even know it was coming!

The game encourages save-scumming, trial and error, and luck. You can do the same persuasion twenty times and win none of them in spite of better stats, and then do it again and win without a fuss. It's INCREDIBLY dumb. On top of this, the multiple choices in this game seldom serve to do anything except have an incredibly mild effect on the game, bar one that could SINGLE HANDEDLY LOSE YOU THE GAME in the second act.

Exploration isn't an option so much as a necesity. You HAVE to explore, you HAVE to do everything, because otherwise you are going to Die. Again, and again, and again, and again, and again. You won't have the levels, the gear, or the spells to suceed. Save every five seconds, because sometimes a pack fo seven enemies will just appear and kill you from nowhere, without warning, and you'll die. Now, you might think that because you know where they are you can attack THEM first! Nope. They're not in the game until you trigger the event. There's no way to pre=trigger the ambushes. You will just... have to get ambushed.

I had to restart the entire game multiple times because i died to something i had no knowledge of, and lost HOURS of progress because i was in town or picking up quests and then stumbled across something far too strong for me. Merchants inventories only change when they level up, so good luck finding what you want in the late game.

I still like the game.

The characters are pretty alright. Some are kinda interesting, some are forgettable and some are memorable, like the Cheese Vendor who me and my freind quote every now and again. SOme quests are silly and fun, and are a nice little diversion from the main quest (when you actually figure out what the main quest is). The game has a lot of lore, and a lot of crafting (not that you'll ever need to craft apart from some very specific circumstances that require no crafting skill) and enemies are generally varied and interesting (except for the Immaculates and Orcs, and to a small extent the Goblins)

The enviroments are awesome, seeing spells used is awesome (except from scrolls, which crash the game), and using summons, using tactical combat, and using different builds makes each playthrough fresh (until late in the game where you realise that, you can only use a very small set of builds that basically do the same thing and everything else is terrible and going to get you killed with no warning or reasoning)

Divinity is Mixed for me. Yes, i'd say you should play it, and play it with a freind most importantly. I'd even reccomend using a guide too, so you can minimise the sheer t of some of the things you run into. But some mobs are colossaly strong with no clear exploitable weakness or strategy to beating them, some things like the rock paper scissors persuasion system lead to hours of frustration and unfairness, and the density of mobs, while normally nicely paced, can get frustratingly grouped in later areas.

Don't play this game to 100% it. The end of the game is... lackluster, honestly. If you want to play it, and you should, play with a freind, or just play for fun with a guide and take it slowly, reading everything, doing every quest, and never trying to go too far ahead of the path. Explore everything, do everything, and most of all have fun. The game doesn't really bear replay value as the different choices don't affect much, if anything, and expect some quests to fail because of RNG. Most of all - don't expect the game to be easy.

I enjoyed Divinity, but i won't play it again. Perhaps the Extended Edition will fix my problems

reviewText:
Not having played this game for very long. I am writing an early review of what I think of this game so far. I do recommend this game, although I will talk about both what I find good and bad.

Divinity: Original Sin has a turn-based combat system. I find this combat style was very well done. It is difficult to choose the wrong place to attack if you are paying attention, and it takes strategy to get through the battles. They certainly are not battles that you want to rush into.

However, there is certainly a lot of difficulty early on in Divinity: Original Sin. I currently am Level 3 and Level 3 creatures are very difficult for me. I do rely on my cleric and healing potions a lot to get through them, and even then a party member dies usually. So it is not a game for a casual player who wants to feel above the opposition. Although it is fun, and makes me think I should be more tactical before I turn a corner, and check for enemies.

One issue I have is that quests rely heavily on what is in the dialogue between the characters, because the Journal you have does not depict location well at all and there are no markers. An example is searching for a Church of Legionnaires, and I do not know where this Church is and the Journal does not tell me where to go. It gets very confusing with the amount of dialogue you do before you get around to doing the quests.

Although, the amazing variety of things to do is awesome. If you explore the first city enough, you manage to find qhat seems to be a second main questline that over-arcs everything. On the surfac, it seems like a lot of fun. A very confusing puzzle to piece togetehr as I play and go through this murder-mystery / source-hunting main quest line. Exploring more into the first main questline also opens up the door to more allies to add to your pack, something that becomes very useful early on due to the difficulty of battles.

Divinity: Original Sin after only a few hours seems like such an amazing game. The story is intriguing and catches your interest, and the amount of stories raveled together layered as such makes me want to pour more of my time into it. The combat is fluent and makes you think and act slowly to survive, and when you do level-up it really feels like you have accomplished something.

I highly recommend this game if you think you can handle the difficulty and amount of dialogue.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is the latest entry in the Divinity series of games, chronologically following Divinity: Dragon Commander and preceeding the events of Divine Divinity.  It is also an unbelievably good game and you should play it immediately.

Maybe I should explain.

Original Sin chronicles the tale of two Source Hunters, inquisitorial figures who have been granted vast authority by the Council of Seven, as they travel the world of Rivellon.  The premise is well-trod in other games; crusaders questing to destroy dark Sourcerers, who must face dire threats while keeping themselves from becoming the very monsters they yadda yadda yadda.

But this is a Divinity game.  This is the direct sequel to the game wherein you played an army commander who was also a dragon wearing a jetpack.

Rivellon is an incredible world to explore- one part hilarious, one part tragic, two parts engrossing.  After you've made your way through the tomb which serves as a tutorial, the game world is simply open, the tasks blinking in your journal neither pushing nor pulling.  In our playthrough, my friend and I have found ourselves moving through the world like water; taking the most interesting paths of least resistance and criss-crossing the map in crazed fashion.  Against the backdrop of a town Councillor's murder, we helped a cat find love, or fought the ghosts of pirates, or battled our way slowly through a monsterous hellscape on a whim.  Every screen has something noteworthy taking place on it, even if it's not immediately obvious what,  and NPC conversations, dialogue, environmental cues and short in-game books are meshed seamlessly into a dramatic and intriguing whole.

As far as the cliche-sounding plotline goes, the story may surprise you.  Nearly as soon as the mundane primary quests begin, they are interwoven with a metaplot on a cosmic level- but they remain fulfilling and well-done stories.  Every named character has a tale, and many of them are well-developed and emotional enough to give you an unusual sense of connection to the character.  After a few hours into the story, the game washes its hands of any responsibility it has to give you moral cues, and it pulls no punches with the complexity of the situations you're forced to resolve on a whim.  Lives and fortunes often depend upon a moment's indecision, and entire populations can be decimated due to a loss at rock-paper-scissors.

(I did remind you that this was a Divinity game.  How else would you resolve social conflicts?)

It might be more helpful to think of Divinity: Original Sin as a complex and interwoven series of events rather than a quest.  Most of the situations throughout the world are resolvable through several vectors, and the whole narrative can shift and adapt as you resolve things 'out of order' or shank a hapless character who caught you pawing through their storeroom.  Plots and schedules in the game world exist with some degree of independance- so when I accidentally set a fishing boat on fire and was forced to slay all of the enraged dockworkers, I cut away the thread which would have led me to the location of the mutineer who'd stolen a valuable artifact... but I came across him later anyway.

Speaking of killing, combat in this game is interesting in a way I've seldom seen before.  Proper fights are turn-based, and unbelievably dynamic and well-balanced.  No abilities are lost on the live-time overworld, however, and so encounters can be started after hurling a fireball at an unwitting group, or re-arranging the scenery to form barricades.  Fights are dangerous affairs- the game does not beleive in pulling punches, and being outnumbered is a threat which must be countered with cunning tactics and even emergant changes of planning.

No more dangerous than the world itself, though.  Rivellon is riddled with traps, puzzles and (well) riddles, and a lapse in attention can mean the death of even an over-levelled party.  Death is a serious matter- ressurection scrolls are real, but rare, and even those won't help you if your entire party goes up in flames.  This is a key element of the game; that the things happening on-screen are things you have to pay attention to, lest you walk blithely into the basement of a paranoid trap-maker or idly break a barrel full of oil while an open fire is alight nearby.

Finally, the multiplayer element is excellent.  While (by default, anyway) only two people can play the same game, each one has full control over a character, and frequent opportunities for choices by each player helps to tailor the character to fit both desires.  The game's plot is built with a dual protagonist in mind, and teamwork is absolutely required in even the most routine battles.  Best of all, the game's interconnectivity system allows players to swap items or teleport to the other in a flash, giving each hero freedom to wander the world map while retaining the ability to show up and participate in combat.

Are there problems with this game?  Of course, but they're blessedly minor.  The game has a few more bugs than you might expect, and load times between areas are long.  It's also easy to skip side-quests, and some of the more important ones contain puzzles sufficiently obscure to create serious problems for some players- plus, though the game lets you do what you want and ignore what you don't, skipping the wrong side-quests can cause serious problems later on.  Finally, the game's NPCs have a solid reprotoire of relevant and witty dialog... which they will repeat, ad infinitum.  This can quickly come to grate on the senses, and I have legitimately killed NPCs merely to make them shut up.

Still, these substantive quibbles are minor.  Divinity: Original Sin, is one of the most solid RPG titles which I've seen in years, and more fun to boot.

reviewText:
It's a fun old school crpg, but more than just a nostalgia romp.

You can tell they spent a lot of time polishing the game, because so many little things are right. Automatically rotated quicksaves, roleplaying traits that have a mechanical effect - much more interesting than any karma or alignment system I've seen in a crpg, a pretty good crafting system, unused action points carrying to the next round, fun perks that let you chat with animals, easy and consistent equipment trading amongst party members, a very usable inventory screen, and a sense of humor that pervades the game.

The game doesn't pull punches or provide safety rails, so expect to die a lot. And expect to throw away your first playthrough away once you realize you screwed up your build completely.

There are a few things I'd change in the interface: change gold amounts in bartering to default to balance the current transaction rather than all gold, make single-file the default formation, and make party members more cautious when they auto-follow.

reviewText:
A door was locked so I beat it down with my sword.

9/10

Oh you think I'm being cute?  Name the last time a you could break down a locked door using your sword at the cost of the sword's durability.  Or how about using a chill spell in the rain to freeze an ally in order to give them a massive physical defense boost?  Sure they can't move, but it keeps them alive until the healing spell cools down.  Ever done that? No?  How about using one character to distract a guard while the other pickpockets them?  Probably not.

Divinity: Original Sin creates a massive web of mechanics and options to give players incredible amounts of power and balances that by making everything ing hard.  Oh, and friendly fire is always on. Don't worry, there's a quick save for when you blow yourself up.

It's not all serious, though.  In fact, most of the sidequests are absolutely hilarious.  The first fighter's guild you join is a pyramid scheme.  If you choose the talent that lets you talk to animals, there's a fortune telling bull.

This game is amazing.  It gives the player incredible power and not so much as a safety pamphlet as a guide.  You will eviscerate yourself a thousand different ways before reaching Level 5, and that's the fun of it.

reviewText:
Okay, so intially I reviewed this game while it was still in beta, and I recommended it wholeheartedly, however, it has since been released in full, so I thought I would update my review to reflect that.

This game is, for me, one of the best rpg's of recent times. Larian has always seemed, to me at least, like a studio with great ideas, but limited execution. With Original Sin however, they have absolutely smashed that perception of them. This game is no less than a masterpiece.

The story is fairly rich, with deep characters, that have their own motives and personalities. It's also pretty damn funny, with many conversations (and in-game books) having genuine laugh-out-loud moments. The combat is intuitive, and well worked, although there are one or two small bugs with it when playing co-operatively, but nothing game or immersion breaking.

The co-op is where this game shines more than most. It is simple, old fashioned, damn good fun. Co-op combat is great, with each player able to feel an important part of the battle, and using abilities to destroy your enemies together is great fun, for example; one player creates a pool of oil beneath your foe, the other then lights it on fire, or perhaps one player teleports an enemy up into the air, before slamming them down into the ground... right in front of your ally, and their massive sword. It rocks, on every level.

So, long story short, if you like rpg's that inherit much from baldur's gate and neverwinter, like your games to be fun and funny in equal measure, enjoy co-op or just enjoy beating things in the head, this is a fantastic game. If you don't like any of those things, then this review probably isn't for you, because anyone that hipster would never do anything so mainstream as to read a review.

Buy it if you like things.

reviewText:
When I was a kid, I found it easy to get lost in a new game. I'd play for hours exploring a new world, despite the lousy graphics (compared to today at least), and not even notice time slipping by. As I've grown older, my responsibilities have grown as well and I've learned to keep a closer eye on the clock so I can get to bed at a decent hour. I've also gotten so used to new games that it's hard for a game to really invoke my sense of wonder and excitement.

Divinity: Original Sin is the first game in a long time to undo all of that. I'm nowhere near finishing it but the gameplay and story and graphics and everything are perfect. Every time I turn it on, I'm drawn into the game so deep that the outside world doesn't exist for a time. When I finally emerge from this finely crafted world and notice the time, I discover I've suddenly lost 6 or more hours of my life. I can no longer play this game on a week night because it guarantees I'll get 5 hours of sleep or less before I have to head to work the next day. Setting an alarm is useless because I'll unconsciously turn off the alarm without even being distracted from the game...

I could write more about this game and how amazing it is but it's hard to find the right words. Here's a few things of note though:

There are no quest markers on the map. If you don't pay close attention to the story and the world, you can easily leave quests unfinished. While some might complain that it makes it too hard, it's also part of what makes the game so immersive. Plus the challenge of deciphering clues to progress is a lot of fun in and of itself.

The music is fantastic. The easter eggs are hilarious. The graphics are gorgeous. The combat is both fun and challenging which is a hard combo to pull off. And despite the turn based nature, combat still somehow feels surprisingly fast paced.

I do have 1 negative comment. The conversation minigame for when 2 characters disagree is annoying to me. The first time or two I thought it was cool but after that... it got old fast. Especially in a single player game where I'm forced to either have both my characters always agree or I have to play a minigame where I may or may not get the actual outcome I want. In co-op it's even more annoying because I'd rather make a decision through actual conversation with my partner than through an a repetitive mini-game. When using the game to convince NPCs of something, it's perfect but when the two main characters are making a decision, it annoys me. I'd also like it if during conversations in co-op the second player could have more interaction that just reading chat bubbles over the other players head. Especially because if one player clicks too fast, the other doesn't even get a chance to read them. Other than that, I love this game. And even this little issue isn't enough to stop me from playing.

reviewText:
This CRPG is one of the best out there. The game is played in real-time but the battles are turn-based, with great elemental and landscape interactions. The world itself wonderfully drawn--a nice combination between pretty landscapes and cartoonish monsters. The music is awesome and I enjoy the voicing (I talk to the rats more often than necessary because it makes me giggle). The price is well worth the amount of content for the game ($40). (Edited to add--finished the game at ~91 hours. Awesome value for dollar). The story is engrossing and you make many choices along the way that affect your gameplay. In fact, beware; choices are permanent and have consequences. If you choose to shoot an NPC in the face with a fireball in broad daylight...well, I recommend you save often in case you need to roll back after some instant regret.

The puzzles in this game can be hard, and the most difficult aspect is likely the fact that you have to pay attention to EVERYTHING--there's a lot of story and the game expects you to listen and learn. If you get confused or lost (which happened to us...erm, often....) you might get a little frustrated. Consider all of your actions, pay attention to story and quests, put care into where you put your skill points, and you'll be fine.


My complaints are small: inventory can become unwieldy, and some of the puzzles are hard (or require patience levels that I don't possess). However, the sheer fun of this game more than makes up for the small bugs and there are a lot of surprises waiting inside this game

I give it a 10/10 for co-op.

reviewText:
D:OS is in a word...amazing. Think Baldurs Gates but Co-Op with a little Magicka thrown in as far as spell interaction goes. Nasty archers with fire arrows or pyrokinetic mages have your friends on fire? Use your magician to make it rain and quench the flames...and guess what now everyone is wet and susceptible to being frozen with a chill spell. Not to mention you can fire lightning at a puddle of water or blood to make a stun field.

So many possibilites. Wanna steal from an NPC but they keep walking around? Break up your party and talk to up 3 NPCs separately while you rob them blind. Pick up a talent called Leech and everytime blood toches your character (even their own) they recieve Health. Nasty Melee enemy right in your caster/ranger's face? Teleport him into the sky and drop him on his head (or his friends) for great damage and better position.

So much can be said about this game but know this TACTICS RULE THE DAY. Fully utilizing your party is the key to victory even on normal difficulty. Learn how ALL OF YOUR SKILLS interplay, DO NOT I REPEAT DO NOT stifle your own development by only sticking to Oil/Fire. Nothing can beat a varied party that really knows how to change any situation. And Last but not least FULL ONLINE CO-OP not just some watered down mode.

reviewText:
10/10

The Good: Fantastic CRPG game, reminiscent of bygone days. If you liked the classic Ultima or Fallout series you will love this game. You have utmost freedom in creating your characters and classes. The combat is turned based, ala Xcom. What makes the combat great is the interaction of elements. Make it rain, and opponents get wet. If you now hit them with a ice spell they get frozen. This opens up countless of possible combinations. The story is a bit fantasy cliche, but the world is lovingly crafted, quirky and very immersive. The best part is that it has coop, which is a blast. Your coop partner can literally disagree with you in-game when you speak to NPCs, and change the outcome of a quest.

The Bad: The game does not hold your hands, aside from a small tutorial dungeon in the beginning. There are no quest markers, and little to no explanation about its stats system. Little dialog is spoken, so lots of dialog reading is required to know how to finish quests. If you are the impatient type and are looking for an action-rpg, look elsewhere.

Verdict: Game of the year for me so far. This illustrates nicely what kind of games are possible when developers don't have  publishers breathing down their necks about dumbing down or streamlining their games.

reviewText:
Authors note: Whilst a Kickstarter funder myself, I did not touch the game during its development process  therefore I cannot compare any pre- and post-release changes. This is an early, first impressions review. I shall amend this upon further venturing into the game.

Divinity: Original Sin is Larian Studios latest addition to the Divinity series, going back to its roots as a turn-based RPG set in an open world with unlimited possibilities. You control two customizable characters, who arrive on an Island chasing down sorcerers, fighting off orcs, and investigating the reports of undead activity in the area. Quirky and engaging, Larians Kickstarter darling is a welcome addition to anyones game library.

Original Sin starts you off by letting you customize your two playable characters. You can change their class, appearance, and even their initial stats, if you wish. There are numerous options to choose from, with the classes ranging from fighter to wayfarer, offering varied styles of play, but can probably be grouped into three major roles (coinciding with the three voice pack choices in game): rogue, warrior, and wizard. There are many roles that min-max certain skill sets, while others act as a blend between two major roles. Overall, there is enough variety here to cater to different play styles. Cosmetic customization is also rich, with options to change gender, hair, voice, skin tone, face, and portrait all available.

The game features a very neat art style and visual aesthetic. The world of Original Sin is colourful, vivid, and full of life. The trees sway gently, torches burn brightly, and water flows smoothly  the world feels dynamic and active with every little detail added in. The quality of the games graphics is astoundingly good, while also being somewhat efficient  it runs on Ultra by default on my GTX 765M, and Ive had no issues with it dropping below 30, usually floating at the 40s on FRAPS. The art style is akin to a more realistic Torchlight  colours pop out and everything is somehow cartoonish, but it definitely feels like a believably real representation of its world.

Combat in Original Sin goes about in a turn-based, action point oriented style. It is reminiscent of other classic RPGs such as Fallout 1 and 2. Certain actions cost a certain amount of AP, movement AP cost is dependent on distance (in meters, unsure if you can change this to the empirical format) and certain units are given priority to move first. Various stats affect what weapons and armor you can equip, how certain skills work for your character, hit chance, dodge chance, and inventory space. So far, the combat flows nicely, and is quite enjoyable. One of the more noticeable breaks from the usual AP system is that any unused AP in a turn is carried over, adding more options for your later turns.

A major part of Original Sin is interaction with its various characters, with special focus between the two player characters. Often times, when a decision is to be made, your characters exchange dialog, with each option affecting certain traits of the characters, such as their persuasion, obedience, and altruism.

So far, with roughly two hours in, Original Sin is showing plenty of signs of a good game, and I will definitely invest more time in it to further develop my opinion. It seems like the game is made for coop, with two players controlling one character each. I can see that playing out fairly well, with hilarious results in the inter-character dialog! Overall, I would say that if you were already interested in the game, it wouldnt be such a bad idea to get it, especially if you have a friend playing it as well.

reviewText:
Brilliant cRPG, highly recommend it. Larian have done a terrific job bringing old school RPG into 2014 without compromising or dumbing it down. Pretty much everything you know and love about cRPG is there. Complex character stats, inventory management, wall of texts and no quest marker.
Combat is all turned based, using the action point system. What makes it interesting is the area effect and how the different element interact with each other. Cast a spell to make it rain and enemies become more susceptible to stuns (electricity) or frozen. Drop poison gas or oil and follow it up with a fireball and the gas/oil blows up causing more damage to the affected area. It's going to suck now playing other RPGs and not being able to remove or use hazards to your advantage.
Game was made to be played co-op but if you want to just play it single-player (I did), it'll pretty much play just like any other RPG except you'll have an option to roleplay both characters. A recent patch added personalilties that you can set on your 2 main characters which will let the AI control the other main character you aren't controling in conversation should you want to automate either character's responses.
The story is probably the only real weakness of the game. It's pretty generic fantasy stuff (with a humorous undertone, especially on side quests), but it did keep me engaged enough for the 85 or so hours it took me to finish the game with all side quests done (great btw). The puzzles are, in most cases done pretty well. Some of them might not be obvious right away. You'll have to look around your environment, reading books or talking to the right person for clues. There was 1 or 2 that was convoluted, which lead to trial and error.
The game isn't perfect but I did not run into any game breaking bugs and Larian is constantly updating the game on a regular basis. There's a free toolset that comes with the game so hopefully, we'll be seeing quality user generated content that will keep the game alive for hours after finishing the campaign. We've got 3 more cRPGs coming out (Wasteland 2, Torment and Pillars of Eternity), Larian was the first out of the gate and it has set a pretty high bar for the rest to follow.

reviewText:
Playing Divinity honestly felt like playing Dungeons and Dragons with a fairly creative DM who managed to  up some times.

The game is a turned based magic and sorcery RPG, with a lot of bizarre magic interactions. Let's say that there's a fire in your way. Casting rain will put out the fire, leaving behind a steam cloud that blocks line of sight and a bunch of puddles. Casting lightning on the puddles will then cause them to be electrified, stunning anyone who walks over them. There are all sorts of elemental interactions like this can make for fairly deep and nuanced combat.

The story is fairly compelling, with a well realized world and interesting intrigue between different players. I played through this game 100% coop and think that it deserves to be lauded for making a deep RPG with an interesting story that actively encourages people to work together. I feel that that's the next step for gaming. We've had plenty of Left 4 Dead-ish action co op games, but now I feel that story-oriented coop can become a real thing.

But unfortunately, the game needs some simple UI adjustments to become a bit more coop friendly. If you have two different people doing two different things in a game, then you need to clearly deliver all plot essential dialogue to both players. Often I'd be off crafting something and my partner would go and have an important conversation and I'd be left wondering what the heck was going on. Considering that the game gives you a teleport pyramid thing early on, it really wouldn't have hurt to pull the other player to important dialogues the moment they started (and to pop a dialogue window for both players the moment said dialogue began).

Another problem is that the game's puzzles are completely awful. Any puzzle where you have to run around a room looking for a button to press (which usually is impossible to see with the default camera angle) is not really a puzzle at all. Portal 2 taught us that group puzzle solving can be incredibly fun and there are moments when I got that same high of being able to figure out a solution and brag about it, but those moments were heavily outweighed by the pixel hunt puzzles.

With a little more polish in these departments, this would have been a superb game. As it stands right now, I'd call it a pretty good game (maybe even a REALLY good game) that is certainly moving in the right direction.

If they make an expansion pack, I'll certainly get it.

reviewText:
Take one of the older Black Isle Studio games, mix in modern tabletop gaming wisdom, the tiniest dash of JRPG charm, a little bit of Ultima's morality (and furniture moving), and stick a co-op cherry on top. Divinity is an absolute blast of an RPG that gets just about everything perfectly right.

You are able to tailor each one of your characters into a specific role, and the possibilities are highly varied. Templates are offered to help get you started if you like. Anything from front-line tank, to mobile assassin, to a wizard that manipulates and shuts down the environment and uses his pets for the wetwork, to a support character that crafts the party wicked new equipment, or who enhances the treasures they already own, but there's no reason you can't treat it as a buffet and pick up a little bit of everything. Customization goes beyond the normal STR/DEX/INT stats into independent skills you can level up, abilities you can learn, and (most fun of all) fallout-style perks. Character customization doesn't stop there. There are multiple opportunities to engage in dialog with other NPCs, or even your friend/party if you are playing co-op. Your answers here define your personality traits. Reflect carefully upon them, for you are called upon in certain situations to roleplay your character consistently with previous choices!

Combat is highly tactical and turn based. I started out as an air wizard, but later found that pincushioning baddies in the back was a lot more fun for me. Those magic points weren't wasted, as they translated into excellent crowd control abilities. Charm one monster, teleport another away, then stab a third in the back. Wonderful. The power player is amply rewarded, while still allowing you the freedom to make some happy mistakes in customizing your character. Especially in the first quarter of the game, there were a few fights that we bullheadedly jumped into despite being far out of our EXP league, but we would boobytrap the entire environment, move tables and chairs around to create killing zones, and set up devastating openers and were able to squeak by. In the last quarter of the game, our min/maxed characters were so overwhelming that if we were able to get enough of an opening and get all our buffs & debuffs in line, there were very few monsters (boss or otherwise) that we couldn't take out in a single volley. This was our reward for playing so aggressively. That is not to say that combat ever became trivial or tedious, despite being a combat oriented RPG, it is amazing how memorable each and every fight was. There was always some situation that was slightly new, that required us to think a little bit differently. I don't know how they pulled it off, but the results are amazing.

I had hesitations playing an RPG game as CO-OP, but those reservations were muted almost immediately. Our very first encounter in the game resulted in us having a disagreement about how to proceed. We resolved that dispute using a mini-game, but each of our characters choices was still reflected in our personality matrix that was being built, so no one feels like they're being bulldozed or wasting their time. Your objection has been noted in the logs. Having a friend who specializes and is familiar with their specific character during combat is also a relief - everyone knows their job and how to perform it best.

The perfection of Divinity is what leads its rough patches to stand out in even starker detail. Keeping the storyline straight in single player might be hard enough, but in co-op at points it became very difficult. reviewText:
[Please note: I reserve to change this review as I proceed in the adventure and as game patches come in].

Divinity: Original Sin is a solid classic-style RPG, focused on co-op play (but absolutely enjoyable in solo play as well) with very modern graphics and with *lots* of things to do.

A first thing to consider: this game is hard if you compare it to most contemporary titles -- you will die multiple times if you are not careful, trust me, so save often! -- and it does not take you by hand, it lets you explore the world and do what you like, when you like it; it feels old-school in a way, but at the same time extremely fresh. And speaking of it, the game world is enormous and should provide from 60 to 100 hours of fun, even without considering any of the user generated content that fans will provide on the Steam Workshop.

The levelling system is classless so you can literally become anything you like (although the game delivers tens of starting archetypes if you don't want to mess too much with all the traits and abilities): for example, you can start as a warrior and acquire magical skills later in the game as you level up and assign points accordingly.

Combat is tactical and turn-based and therefore quite complex... but don't worry, it's fun and you can plan your next move without being in a hurry!

The post-launch lack of AI personalities" for your party members has been fixed
date: and therefore now in singleplayer you can enjoy dialogues and banter with your own party members without having to pick all lines for everybody. :P\n\nOverall I'm very impressed with this game
recommended: and I am looking forward to play it for much time to come. If you like CRPGs like me... get it
hoursPlayed: you won't be disappointed.\n\nMy vote: 9 / 10"

reviewText:
What a stunning achievement from a former Kickstarter.  Aces across the board.

The graphics are nice and the environment is both beautiful as well as interactive, as during combat you can add water, fire, smoke, steam, and other effects to change the tide of battle.  These effect sight lines and cause damage.

The combat is turn-based and full of great magical spells.  I also enjoy having to balance healing with aggression.

There are 12 classes, but each is very customizable. There are many unique abilities, skills, attributes, and crafts for you to play around with.

This is an old-school RPG game, so expect 15 hours of walking and talking to citizens before you hit level 4 -- at which point you will have enough skill and companions to survive a fight.  Also, you can kite enemies back to the guards or into areas full of traps to gain advantages.

There are TONS of items in the game, but most you'll never use and most you'll sell.  There seems to be a finite amount of gold in this world, and I've collected what feels like most of it.  Second reroll = 18hrs = 23K.  Don't buy anything; play for long enough and it will drop (except for pants; none of my people have pants and I don't know why).

Lots of treasure chests to dig up.

Each combat area gives you a different feel with different challenges.

The story is a ton of fun, though it get's a little weird when they added all the outerspace stuff.  So that part I didn't like.  But the main plot is about murder with a twist and I like that.

I can't tell you how much I enjoyed this game -- first in beta and now live.  It's a must own for the RPG crowd and here's hoping they decide to make a sequel.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin has two very big thumbs up from me.  It's one of the best RPG's I've played in a long, long time. That said, there certainly are a few issues which I'm sure will be remedied over time. The freedom that the player has while clumsily wandering throughout the very large and immersive world is unparalleled.  Being able to do whatever I want, whatever I want - good or bad is powerful.  That kind of freedom really allows the player to be a part of the world and really drive where the game goes (or doesn't go).

reviewText:
Brilliant cRPG, highly recommend it. Larian have done a terrific job bringing old school RPG into 2014 without compromising or dumbing it down. Pretty much everything you know and love about cRPG is there. Complex character stats, inventory management, wall of texts and no quest marker.
Combat is all turned based, using the action point system. What makes it interesting is the area effect and how the different element interact with each other. Cast a spell to make it rain and enemies become more susceptible to stuns (electricity) or frozen. Drop poison gas or oil and follow it up with a fireball and the gas/oil blows up causing more damage to the affected area. It's going to suck now playing other RPGs and not being able to remove or use hazards to your advantage.
Game was made to be played co-op but if you want to just play it single-player (I did), it'll pretty much play just like any other RPG except you'll have an option to roleplay both characters. A recent patch added personalilties that you can set on your 2 main characters which will let the AI control the other main character you aren't controling in conversation should you want to automate either character's responses.
The story is probably the only real weakness of the game. It's pretty generic fantasy stuff (with a humorous undertone, especially on side quests), but it did keep me engaged enough for the 85 or so hours it took me to finish the game with all side quests done (great btw). The puzzles are, in most cases done pretty well. Some of them might not be obvious right away. You'll have to look around your environment, reading books or talking to the right person for clues. There was 1 or 2 that was convoluted, which lead to trial and error.
The game isn't perfect but I did not run into any game breaking bugs and Larian is constantly updating the game on a regular basis. There's a free toolset that comes with the game so hopefully, we'll be seeing quality user generated content that will keep the game alive for hours after finishing the campaign. We've got 3 more cRPGs coming out (Wasteland 2, Torment and Pillars of Eternity), Larian was the first out of the gate and it has set a pretty high bar for the rest to follow.
